description:
The service is great 
The food is hearty and heart felt 
So in love with this space 
Thank you Ill be back
author: Om H.

description:
CASH ONLY.

If it weren't cash only this place would get a solid 4 from me but man this place is a well-frequented establishment with food that's not necessarily super cheap so I would expect they could accept credit but nah. Usually this wouldn't mean a star less but they also don't have an ATM machine on the premises. Thankfully there's one across the street in a corner store otherwise I would NOTTT have been able to afford my breakfast this morning.

Anyway, cute local café. This place is walking distance from Glen Park BART. I got the Big Scramble which was a scramble with ground chuck; comes with potatoes and toast and was ~$11. They seem to be pretty busy on the weekends but the table turnaround time is really fast, though they do seem to be rushing you out at times.

I had an ok time here. Food was pretty average. Service was attentive (they refilled my coffee maybe every like... 3 minutes lol) but I kinda wish they weren't cash only. I might come back, just not that often. Tyger's is kinda forgettable.
author: Brian W.

description:
Service was 5 stars.  So friendly and warm.  
Food was realistically closer to 3 stars.  Average/good but not great - but the experience as a whole was really good.
author: Madhuri K.

description:
Not 4 stars because it is pretty average diner food. The omelette was a bit bland and oily, but I'm not opposed to revisiting and trying something else. The hash browns and toast were on point, but nothing else was extraordinary. 

Very good service and on point with the coffee. I must have had 5 cups. 

Will try again. Until next time!
author: Heihachiro K.

description:
First time here w bf for brunch. We ordered French toast vegetable scramble and California scramble. Decent food, but their potatoes and bread was mostly burned..... I'll request not to burn the potatoes next time! I'll def. come back again. 
Btw CASH ONLY!
author: Lulu L.

description: Great hole-in-the-wall place for breakfast! This cute little neighborhood has a lively vibe, and this little greasy spoon is a winner and a local's favorite. I had the breakfast burrito and it was so large that I took half home for dinner. Try Tyger's next time you're in the area.
author: Em K.

description:
I got a tiny, burger with bacon and avocado for 14.2 and it didn't even had fries on the side! My friend ordered eggs with sausage and it was super runny. When we asked a guy to exchange them the guy was super rude.He rolled his eyes and was explaining that that's how they always cook it while it was in front for us swimming already in water. 
Experience was very disapointing and unpleasant.
author: Oksana G.

description:
It's an easy 5 stars for what it is... a casual neighborhood diner catering to one of the last remaining SF neighborhoods where neighbors actually know their neighbors. I can see how someone from across town wouldn't appreciate it, but for locals it's a gem. Typical cozy diner foods. Some standouts are the: pancakes (huge and fluffy); Cheese-Burgers (greasy goodness); chicken fried steak and eggs (hangover cure); and the classic eggs, bacon, potatoes, toast. Of and really good coffee (A hint of chicory? I need to ask next time). 

Very kind, hardworking staff. Cash only... but that's really no big deal, there are 5 ATMs within a 2 block radius. Why insist on helping Visa, MasterCard and credit card companies make money off hard-working mom-and-pop businesses?
author: Jay E.

description: Used to dine here infrequently, but the last meal I had was literally smothered in cooking oil- I'm talking a lake of maybe 1/4-1/2 cup of cooking oil filling the plate under my potatoes. I nearly vomited,  swore never to return (and stuck to that vow for 15 years).
author: T J.

description:
I really used to like Tygers. Okay casual/basic breakfast and diner food and yay for offering turkey bacon. Not super expensive. Unfortunately my husband and I got harassed by another customer today, and the staff did little to stop it.

The man was an older man with white hair, who 'claimed' his spot at the counter by slamming down his newspaper, getting in my face, and aggressively telling us to leave our seats despite the fact that we were seated already (by the restaurant staff). Oh, and there was a single seat open elsewhere. I understand this man may be an eccentric fixture who frequents often (yada yada) and likes his same spot, but no one has the right to harass someone else and say extraordinary rude things to them. 

After being continually harassed by this man, we left. Not coming back. Maybe the restaurant should decided if they want to deal with this guy or keep losing customers.
author: Michelle K.

description: Staple of Glen park. Great diner food. Order takeout several mornings a week. The sourdough toast and potatoes are great.
author: Merv A.

description: Ok but not as good as other places friendly staff and reasonable prices. Next time just straight bacon m eggs!
author: Paul D.

description: I'm not into bad mouthing anyone but the food here is bland as all get out. I came here because I saw two people eating what looked to be a tasty looking burger from the window. I decided to roll the dice. I came here and the food was just awful. This place is also old and decrepit. I think they are probably not bad people. They just don't seem to know how to run a restaurant. I don't think I'll be trying anything here in the future.
author: Anthony V.

description: Typical dinner. Exactly what you would expect in food. Service is friendly and prompt. Pricing makes sense. I would hit this again.
author: Nika C.

description: While the staff were incredibly kind, the food was not very good. I ordered an egg scramble with country potatoes and neither the eggs nor the potatoes were very flavorful. Food was very bland. My husband ordered the banger sausage with 2 eggs and potatoes, and had the same sentiment about the food. I wouldn't go back.
author: Samantha B.

description: Good place for a lazy sunday breakfast. It is located in the cute and cozy neighborhood of Glen Park. Tyger's is strategically placed close to the Bart station. The owner is a very energetic, friendly and hardworking lady. This place is very kid friendly and they even let kids use the old-school register to pay for the bill. The food is good. The country fries are well made and the pancakes and fluffy.
author: Victoria L.

description:
This place serves heavy comfort food. I don't usually come here unless I'm starving because my food coma is intense. Thank god it's now acceptable to wear yoga pants to weekend brunch cause my jeans would not have the level of stretch needed.

It's a local diner with just locals stopping by. Food is average, service is quick, and the space is decently clean.
author: Josephine C.

description:
Good lord. Where do I start? Walking in it was a quite as a library, a little music even if bad is better then feeling like you should whisper. Huevos ranchers might have been the worst I have ever had. Dirty Rice? Not sure what else was in there but the slice of Swiss cheese was just wrong. My daughter who loves pancakes didn't even finish them... Both plates unfinished yet no question regarding if we liked the meal.

#feelingill
author: David B.

description: Tyger's has seasonal specials like pumpkin walnut pancakes and spiced apple pancakes that are delicious. They also have a lot of other vegetarian options like vegan sausage and good home fries.  It has a homey vibe and adds to the charm of Glen Park.
author: Rhiannon B.

description: Good greasy spoon diner, great service. I got the linguisa sausages and eggs special, rye toast wasn't great and eggs and potatoes needed quite a bit of extra seasoning, but the sausages were very flavorful and snappy. We got a couple of pumpkin walnut pancakes; they were quite large and very good. Also tried a couple of buttermilk pancakes, and they were probably the best part of it all; pancakes are definitely Tyger's specialty. It's probably not a place I'll crave later, but it's a great choice for breakfast and is open early. Cash only!
author: AJ P.

description: Amazing diner food! About maybe 3 min away from the Glenn Park BART Station. I had the chicken fried steak and eggs. Superb
author: Saeed R.

description: Decided to venture into glen park neighborhood for breakfast since we typically eat in the mission and wanted to change it up a bit. Boy did we choose the wrong place service was pretty bad it took forever to get our order in.. in fact a table that showed up ten minutes after us was had their order taken before us. I had the steak and eggs and my gf had the veggie omlette. My steak was extremely tough even though I ordered it medium rare and the gfs omlette was extremely bland.. I'm pretty sure we won't be back again.. oh btw it's cash only
author: Jared V.

description:
Went in today looking for a quiet spot to sip coffee and read the paper after smoking a fatty. I had my choice of tables so I took the one in the corner, away from all the happy people and their optimistic vibes. The food was tasty and the waitress can only be described as "cool as fuck." 

Don't be a chump, carry cash!
author: Dro K.

description: Stop in for breakfast and that's exactly what I got some good ole'down breakfast as well a great hospitality atmosphere just like in my Grandma's kitchen~
author: Jeberechiah S.

description:
So I came here for brunch with my sweetheart. When we walked in the first thing I noticed was it reminded me of an old folks home. Basically it lacks creativity. The food was average. My French toast had a weird taste to it because of the butter they used and my bacon was too salty. I'm glad they gave me water. Coffee was great tho! The sever was great as well. Always smiling and was very helpful when helping us make up our indecisive.

If I would have to pick between spending my last $20.00 on food here or another place. I would choose another place.
author: Monee C.

description: We love Tyger Cafe. Everything about this place is wonderful. So wonderful in fact that since we moved away from the Glen Park neighborhood to Berkeley we took BART into the city specifically to eat there. I wish every neighborhood had a breakfast place as special. The food is tasty and affordable, and the service is always friendly.
author: John H.

description:
I frequently ate here many moons ago. It was a great place to grab a quick no-frills breakfast--even had my first British Banger here! IIRC Tyger was the name of the owner/cook working his tail off in the kitchen. Fast forward at least 12 years...decided to stop in with my family, bragging about how awesome this diner *was*.  Not anymore. The service was abominable, our food arrived cold and it took forever to get our check. Wasn't super busy at the time, so this was surprising. I generally don't cross a place off my list after one visit, especially an old favorite, so I decided to stop in again to give it another chance. Midweek breakfast, handful of tables were full...many open ones. Told to take a seat anywhere. I sat for a quite a bit while the waitress walked over to two tables and took their orders, gave them coffee. I didn't even have a menu. No problem...I grabbed one from the counter. Sat for longer while she completely ignored me and brought over a couple of dishes to one of the tables. In walk an couple--they're told to sit anywhere. I'm still sitting, waiting for at least a cup of coffee. After the waitress is done with the table she was waiting, she walks past me again and ignores me. Then she walks over with menus and coffee for the couple who just walked in. I left and grabbed a cold coffee from the Canyon Market.
I love my old reliable neighborhood hangs where I can get a decent no-frills meal for a decent price. Tyger's is no longer one of them. Disappointing.
author: Amelia C.

description:
Chill place.  Late lunch, around 2 pm, I was the only customer, made me a little skeptical but it was very good.  Service was fast, waitress was sweet.  I was able to enjoy my mid-day solitude. 

Burger was done to my likeness, can't complain.   Next time I may go for breakfast food.
author: Sonnett S.

description: Cash only. Breakfast parking has always been easy for me during the week. This is not a driving destination; rather a walkable place for the locals. It's open at 7am and the daily specials are unique. This morning I had chicken enchiladas and eggs. The quality of the groceries are comparable to most of the other city breakfast cafes.
author: Stanley J.

description:
This place is so cute. My first time here. I live in the neighborhood and I've been wanting to try this place.

Got the country breakfast which included pancakes, choice of meat and two eggs.

I got the blueberry pancakes with bacon and sausage. It was filling and really flavorful. I want to come back to try the breakfast burrito. 

Cash only here.
author: Jenna R.

description:
DELICIOUS HANDMADE PANCAKES!

This is an awesome place for a local neighborhood gem for brunch!  I was here with my coworker during the week and decided to order their FRESH HANDMADE BANANA PANCAKE with TWO EGGS AND SAUSAGE!  It was delicious!  They gave me a large portion and the service was excellent!

I was told that they have been around for a very long time.  My coworker even knew the owners and he grew up with their son and they went to school together!  

They also have a large menu and so you can order whatever your hearts desire!  

If you are looking for a hearty fresh breakfast with large portions and excellent service - you have to stop by at Tyger's!
author: Edwin R.

description:
Its a mediocre diner in Glen Park. They have a simple menu consisting of eggs, pancakes, and 90's diner mini cereal boxes. 

I forget if they are cash only or not but you get a lot for your buck here. Service is attentive and food comes out quite quickly. If you walk down Diamond past Bello's and Canyon Market, its on the corner under the construction.
author: Daanyaal K.

description: I come here often despite the food being pretty crappy. Why, I cannot explain. I wish they cared more about cooking well.
author: Paul A.

description: Decent diner food and coffee at affordable prices in the Glen Park area. Portions are huge and filling! Sadly, I found a piece of hair in my omelette and just couldn't finish it, despite how tasty and delicious the omelette had been. Maybe hairnets would be a good suggestion?
author: Joanne K.

description: Dirty cups, dirty space. Food looked nasty...tasted OK. Lemonade was $4. It wasn't fresh.
author: Sarah R.

description:
Came here on a Sunday afternoon and it was pretty empty. You can choose where you want to sit and they a decent breakfast selection. I ordered the omelette with the sausage, mushroom, avocado, and cheese and it came with a side of potatoes. Portion was pretty big for me. I was only able to eat about half of my plate, but I felt like it was kinda lacking in flavor. It tasted like something I could've made...and that's coming from someone who doesn't really know how to cook. 

Overall food isn't bad, but I will pass and find something more savory or flavorful.
author: Renee Y.

description: Cute place to have some delish brunch! Try the huevos rancheros! Salsa tasted so fresh! Really recommend this place for a fulfilling breakfast
author: Lissett D.

description:
I am so liking this diner and will have to make another stop to try something else from the menu. The next item of the menu to try will be the pancakes on my next visit. A gem in Glen Park! There's a fair amount of seating for about 20-30 customers. The staff members and patrons here seem very friendly which is a good thing. Service is definitely prompt - that's another good thing.

Here's what I ordered today:
Two eggs (scrambled) which came with country potatoes and a side of toast (I chose whole wheat).

Hours of Operation:
7:00 am - 3:30 pm everyday

It is close to Glen Park BART Station!

Parking: Mostly street / metered parking

Price Range: $

This place is "CASH ONLY"
author: Bennett W.

description: I've been going here since I was a little girl and I just love it. If your looking for a place to eat with the family and have a good yummy breakfast then this is the place to go, slightly expensive but I promise it's worth it.
author: Alia G.

description:
Located on the corner of Diamond and Chenery St in Glen Park, this place offers a homey mom & pops feel. They have steel gates in front of the front door, which makes it seem like it's closed; keep on eye on the look out for the open sign! 

Entering, we were welcomed by the homey atmosphere this place has to offer; an old fashioned looking diner, families eating breakfast, and the welcoming owners who seated us immediately. The size of this place is small, so I wouldn't recommend you bringing in a group of people; the most I'd say you can bring per table is probably a family of four. Service is friendly, as they're quick to clean up your plate and they come by to ask if everything is okay. They also have specials written on a whiteboard behind the cash register. 

The food was mediocre to me. I opted for the French Toast Combo (~$10) which consisted of a choice of meat [bacon!], eggs, and french toast.The french toast and eggs were mediocre - a little plus to the toast for being a little more delicious! But the bacon was too salty for my taste.. 

I think this diner is great for the location if you would like mom & pops feel!
author: Mandy G.

description: Wow! What a fantastic breakfast spot. I first came here when I was a kid, but just recently came back as an adult. Not much has changed! I think that's great. I was craving a big breakfast in the morning and knew this would be the place to go in Glen Park. The waitress immediately greeted us good morning and had some small talk. I went on to order the country fried steak with two over easy eggs, sourdough toast, and potatoes. The food came in a timely manner. The ambiance is pretty simple, nice, and quiet, which I value during the morning. Tyger's is a great mom and pop shop that serves terrific breakfast. There's not a long line or wait, not a bunch of young hipsters taking a bunch of photos before they eat. Just some old fashioned people reading the newspaper and taking a breather before they start their day. This place could even make me a morning person. Come prepared with cash since that's all they accept. The waitress was really nice too, I accidentally handed her a bart ticket and she says, "We don't accept bart tickets here!" Was a pretty funny joke in my opinion and goes to show they care about the customer.
author: Dan G.

description: have been going to Tyger's for nearly 20 years, but the most recent time will be the last. The place always had a line of people waiting outside on weekend mornings, but no longer. Maybe new owners, plus a new chef, but if so, they should invest in updating the interior. The breakfast special I had was the corned beef hash, always a favorite, but this time not only was the hash soggy and basically inedible, but the price has nearly doubled. A plate special of corned beef hash, 2 eggs, toast and coffee with a modest tip set me back $18.50, whereas just a couple years ago, a much better tasting dish with coffee and tip would have been under $10. Why the huge increase?  I looked at the menu and was blown away with their new prices. A short stack (2) pancakes for $8.50?  c'mon.... used to be under $4. They're using the same utensils, plates and cups as they have used for 20 years, nothing has changed except the prices and quality of the food. Needless to say, I was very disappointed as this was my go-to place for many years. I will not be going back.
author: Gordon S.

description:
I have been coming here for the past 3 years as it was a very close diner that served some decent breakfast. But the past few times that I have been, both the service and the food has drastically decreased in taste and value.

Once I sat at the bar, it took about 10min before anyone acknowledged I was there or took my order. Then 10min later, I was able to see my food waiting on counter for a server to bring it to me. Took about 7min later until the cook had to bring the order to me himself. At this time during the day the diner was not busy at all with only 5 tables filled.

The only thing that the servers were prompt about was giving me my check and taking my money. 

Good luck Tygers, I hope you can get your quality of food and service back soon.
author: Braven S.

description: I decided to eat here for my lunch break, the breakfast was so delicious and came out quick. I have yet to taste better crunchier bacon that this place. I will definitely be back. The only reason it is not 5 stars is because it is cash only and I am one of those people that use my atm card for everything.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Perfect whole in the wall / community cafe! It doesn't look like much, but the food came out QUICK, hot & they had good sized portions ! 3 meals + 3 beverages + tip came out to $41 so def affordable. I'll be back :)
author: Brenda E.

description:
Great little diner! I live in the neighborhood and this is definitely my go to when I want to go out for breakfast, but not something too fancy or too far. Service is good, they're pretty attentive. They've always got some unique specials(Chimichangas and eggs anyone?) and a some special flavor of pancake. I really like their pancakes. ^_^ They also have a decent collection of hot sauces. Food is reasonably priced, and I love the cute neighborhood diner feel of it.
Oh, and fair warning, they are cash only!

Definitely recommend!
author: Zephyr W.

description:
WOOOW at the portions! The size of their pancakes and omelettes are HUGE. I ordered their country breakfast w/ buckwheat pancakes, egg whites, and corned beef hash and my mom ordered the california scramble. When our food arrived we both just said WOW and the waitress (I believe owner) laughed and said, "first time here?" so I guess this is a normal thing hahaha! The pancakes were seriously bigger than my head and it came with two! They were delicious though. I never had buckwheat pancakes but they were soft and a little sweet! Tasted even more glorious with the butter (: the corned beef hash costed more to substitute but it was delicious as well! I thought it could've used a little more salt, but there was salt and hot sauce for me to use on the table. The california scramble was probably one of the biggest omelettes I've ever seen and I didn't really try it because I don't like mushrooms, but I ate a part that had sausage and those pieces are huge little chunks! (Contradictory, I know.) Along with the omelette came with buttered toast (YUM) and some home fries which were so good! It was weird though, they were like home fries but also like hash browns in a way. They were flat and super crispy like hash browns! Regardless, I thought it was cool and above all delicious. 

This is a cute little joint that serves HUGE portions of traditional diner foods, but also with different things like enchiladas and tamales on their menu! I definitely think there's something for everyone, and no doubt will you leave FULLy satisfied. Get it? Also, the owners/waiters were super duper nice! They were so kind and were pleased to accomodate any of your needs. We got 2 coffees and those two orders for $32 which I thought was oretty worth it considering the huge portions. Good food & good service is what you'll find here. Be prepped for the portions though!
author: Holly P.

description: This place is HORRIBLE!  The food was awful, service not any better. I'd suggest just walking across the street to the corner store if you can't wait for the other nearby places, but don't spend your money here!  Pancake was plain, house potatoes were flavorless and soggy, a sausage we ordered was uncooked,  in general the food is GREASY, plain and gross.  This place is for those who care little a bout the taste and quality of their food and those who can not cook.  The meal we got could have been executed better by 8yr old.  I don't like to bash out on places, but this place really needs to bump up their effort..... By the way COFFEE WAS REALLY BAD!
author: Fabiola V.

description:
Went here for the first time today.  Pretty crowded Saturday morning... had to wait a couple minutes.  Fare is classic greasy spoon... quality on par with what you'd expect for atmosphere and reasonable prices.  Coffee was fine, though refills came infrequently.

The remarkable part was their turkey.  I had a turkey omelet that include their turkey sausage, which was tasty, spiced, and plentiful.  I also like that they had a turkey club on the menu that had turkey ham, turkey bacon, and turkey on it.  I have never seen that before and it seems like a great way to avoid pork, which i do.
author: G M.

description:
A quick and rather inexpensive to indulge in an American meal. 

Came in thirty minutes before closing and was happily served. I'm not usually the type of customer to show up before things are wrapping up, but I definitely felt accommodated and cared for as soon as I stepped in.
author: Ryan K.

description: Clean, friendly and the food is must try. Very happy I stopped here.  service is fast too so that's  a plus.
author: Juan P.

description: Best hole in the wall breakfast spot in SF in my opinion. Everytime I'm here I feel like family and the food instantly gives me a food coma
author: Francisco O.

description:
Mediocre at best. It's not a diner, whatever some reviewers are writing. It's a local breakfast and lunch cafe servings eggs, pancakes, BLTs and burgers. My eggs were cooked correctly, but the homefries were parboiled, followed by an inadequate time on a grill (not crisp at all, just cold and unappetising). The vegan sausages were heated, but not browned. For $9.25, I expect better quality. $7.25 gets you two pieces of poorly cooked French toast with cheap flavorless syrup. 

And the place doesn't seem clean. It's painted from about 6 foot down, but above are age- and fume-stained textured walls and ceiling with a few cobwebs adhering to the raised areas and fixtures. I'm surprised the health department doesn't require a thorough cleaning. 

Won't be back.
author: Rebecca S.

description: Cute old school neighborhood coffee shop.  Normally this would be a 3 star review but I was with my favorite person in the world...so 1 extra star just because of that.  I was looking forward to the corned beef hash but apparently this just doesn't happen on a weekday, so we made do with omelets...tasty and filling but just average.  Definitely a good spot if you're in the neighborhood and need a hearty breakfast.
author: Jennifer G.

description: Nice neighborhood diner with some tasty food options.  I tried the Country fried steak and I got say it's one of the best I've had.  My girlfriend had the breakfast burrito and I had a little bit from it, and it was just as tasty. Cash only people, but theres a bunch of BofA ATMs around. I will definitely come back before I head back home.
author: Juan A.

description:
A typical old time corner joint that has been there for over 20 years.  I would agree with another yelper.  The food is mediocre.  

Service is very neighborly and efficient.  My coffee cup was always full.

My breakfast buddies like it here.  I'd go back with them.  On my own, no.  It's really 2 1/2 stars.
author: Debbie T.

description:
I always see a long line waiting outside Tygers when I drop by eggettes for a drink and decided to wake up extra early with my siblings to check this place out. As we were getting close, it hit 10am, and I thought in my head that there would be no one there. Little did I know, there were already people inside, some waiting inside, and some waiting inside. We waited for about 10 minutes and got a nice seat in the back corner of this compact restaurant.

It's small, but has a really homey, old diner feeling. There was only one light on since the natural light surrounded the restaurant and a fan was shuffling air around the room. The waitress that served us was very kind. She greeted us with a smile and instantly asked us what we wanted to drink. She walks away and a man brings our waters and menus right after.

I ordered the french toast combo. Which came with 2 cut french toast slices, 4 sausages, and 2 scrambled eggs. The eggs were slimy, but I kinda liked it that way. The sausages were dry, but my siblings seemed to have enjoyed it. The french toast was crunchy on the outside but soggy in the middle. Not one of the best I've ever had... but I was definitely full!

My sister ordered the turkey sausage, avacado, and jack cheese omelet. I felt like the omelets were most worth it. The menu doesnt mention that the omelets come with home fries (their version of hash browns) and toast though. So don't order it on the side! It is HUGE, and super filling.

My brother ordered the bacon, mushroom, swiss cheese omelet. The fillings were all on one side of the omelet but eh, he still liked it. He said he would never get sourdough toast again though, "it's too sour..." haha.

Other than that, the service is great, and the price is decent. They came by to refill our water a couple times and that's sometimes rare at a busy restaurant. I've honestly had better breakfast food though. I saw that their pancakes are huge! I want to definitely try that next time

And oh! They're cash only!
author: Linda K.

description:
Cycles.

Two excellent hours of Max Graham for listening: https://soundcloud.com/maxgraham/maxgraham-presents-cycles-4?in=maxgraham/sets/max-graham-presents-cycles

Five incredible hours of Max Graham that requires eating: http://audiosf.com/event/max-graham-12-05/

Fortunately Glen Park's favorite (and only) greasy spoon provided for the night of (turkey burger) and morning after (pancake sandwich with egg whites and turkey sausage).

Impressed with the friendly service (predicted no mayo on the burger), price (less than $20), and both the generous portions and the intense flavor.

Burger was especially delicious. Pancakes were massive.

Which was great because after 5+ hours of Max was ready to cycle through everything.
author: Jason B.

description: Great little neighborhood diner/coffee house. The coffee is not gourmet, but it is good enough (they do not serve instant coffee, btw). The food is classic greasy spoon diner style. My daughter likes eating here when she is off or sick at home.  The workers are friendly, and always ask about the family.  Yes, I absolutely recommend this place.
author: Conrad A.

description: The place wasn't anything amazing. I have no idea why everyone thinks this place is so amazing. The food had no flavor. Yes the pancakes were big but at the same time the flavor wasn't all there. My girlfriends food wasn't good at all, it needed so many condiments to make it even taste a little good. The coffee tasted like water, and this is coming from someone that drinks their coffee black. I'm sorry to say but or instant coffee at home was stronger and better. I'm sorry to say this but I would not be coming back and I would not recommend this place at all.
author: Antonio C.

description: This place is alright. I came here with my mom for breakfast. The pancakes were ok and the hot chocolate was ok. I would rather go to IHOP for breakfast that here. This place is not the place for breakfast.
author: Isaac H.

description:
Nice small diner. I like coming here for "business" meetings or taking my mom out to breakfast when she comes to visit me because it's a nice homey place. The workers are nice and they are very attentive for my coffee. Great for simple breakfast/lunch.
Wish they took cards.
author: Kieran B.

description: Love the food...great mom and pop place to eat...close to bart, bustops, and shops...prices are resonable...if u like classic diner this is a good choice...
author: Alfredo G.

description: Very good stop for breakfast and prices were very reasonable - cheaper than Santa Rosa for equally good food!  I'm not a big eat-out pancake man as I prefer mine made at home, but these were really tasty and I was wishing I had some for dinner tonight!  And the turkey bacon was by far more tasty and a lot less fat than the regular bacon, which my friend hat.  Excellent, friendly fast service and decent coffee. Not haute cuisine but definitely all-American breakfast.
author: Mark O.

description: Not good. The waitress/owner is really polite but the food is at best average. I've been there many times because of the lack of other options in the neighborhood but I decided that it's not worth any more. Potatoes are always burned and at the same time under-cooked-- not sure how they are able to achieve both qualities. My poached eggs are hard cooked and swimming in water and oil. Sausage is edible but again I wouldn't call it delicious. Go to the crape place around the corner for a nice breakfast.
author: Rositsa K.

description: The owner(?)/waiter was really nice and attentive (almost too much so - it seemed like he was hovering over us at certain times during the meal) constantly offering to refill my coffee and water. I probably should have ordered breakfast but went with a burger instead. It was pretty mediocre for $10 - the undercooked fries had an odd taste to them, like they'd been fried in oil that had once had a fish patty or something in it. I might go back again for breakfast when I'm in the neighborhood, but definitely wouldn't make a special trip. Seemed pretty busy for mid-day on Christmas Eve, so I'm guessing that it has quite a few neighborhood regulars/fans.
author: Sergio S.

description:
We stopped into this cute little community cafe on a lark the other morning.

Though Tygers was bustling and full of people, we were seated and our order was taken pretty quickly. The service was wonderful, especially for how busy they were and their prices were on the lower side for a cafe of their type, especially one in SF.

The downside was that they only took cash and sadly, their food quality didn't seem to be the best. They also didn't have a lot of selection in their menu.

I'd come back but I doubt I'd order more than their pancakes or their toast again.
author: Meg T.

description: I frequent this place. Good decent home cooking.  Consistent service, nice atmosphere.
author: Marvelous Margaret M.

description:
It was exactly what I expected--down to the refilled Heinz bottles that look like they've been there since ancient Egyptian times.

I generally am pretty good at cooking breakfast myself at a fraction of the price, but I really suck at making good homefries.  I was hoping that Tygers would one-up me in that regard, but they were decidedly average.

But overall this is a decent diner that charges a fair price, so I'll be back some day when I'm feeling extra lazy and can't take 10 minutes to fry up some bacon and eggs.
author: Rocco B.

description: Huge portions...friendly staff...good ole fashion home cooking.  Order the Country Breakfast with the special pancake on the board for the day...you will want to take a nap after it!
author: Spencer Q.

description: I can't say enough positive things about Tyger. My family and I live in Glen Park and frequent this cafe at least twice a month. We prefer the breakfast menu to the lunch. Lunch reminds me of an old school diner & in my opinion there's nothing wrong with that. But their breakfast has always satisfied our taste buds. Don't forget to peek at the specials board hanging on the wall behind the bar. The pancakes are fluffy and huge! Great if you like to share! Norma is polite and has a calming way about her. Our children are always treated like family. The cooks even make Mickey Mouse pancakes for them without us asking. Definitely the earlier you can get there the better, but you must try this place out!
author: Brittany W.

description: Actually 2 1\2 stars. This place is a hit or miss. I'm leaning towards a miss in most instances. The Asian lady who usually seats me is also a hit or miss. I'm refering to overall friendliness. I've eaten at better places.
author: Mike B.

description: This place is tops for its genre. I love it and it's prices. You're not going to have your idea of what breakfast could be totally turned on its head, but you're going to have an enjoyable sit down meal and come away satisfied.
author: Mr. K.

description: I love this place. I live/work in the neighborhood and they are great when it comes to my time issues. I really enjoy the food here and the wait staff always remembers who I am. The portions are very generous. And the prices are comfortable too. The only downfall is they close at 3p.m.
author: Erin L.

description:
Cute little family owned place. I just got slightly annoyed that we were seated first but the couple that came in after us was helped first because I guess they were their regulars. Rude..

The food was OK. Kind of like home cooked food with only salt and pepper as flavoring. I really liked how they cooked their home potatoes and they do serve pretty good portions for the price, other than that I wasn't too impressed.
author: Mau T.

description: The employees are so welcoming and friendly that it almost feels like you're surrounded by family. Other than that, the food is mediocre- nothing special
author: Deanna L.

description:
I'm not sure why they call themselves a "Coffee Shop". They are a diner. Their coffee was average diner coffee.

The food was cheap and plentiful, and the service was attentive. However, the food was disappointing. My omelette was passable (though I felt like I could make a better one at home), but the potatoes on the side were awful. It's like they cut up boiled russet potatoes, piled them onto a dry skillet for 3 minutes, and then sent them out. No seasoning, not sauteed in anything. Gross.

If you want a lot of mediocre breakfast food for cheap, this place is fine. But with all the great brunch options in SF, you're doing yourself a disservice.

Also, they are cash only, which in my opinion is unacceptable in 2015.
author: Steve P.

description:
Ive always liked this place. Make sure to check out the Day's Special that is sometimes written on the board on the wall. Might not be included in the menu. 

//
author: Kim K.

description: This is a hidden spot if you blink twice you'll miss it very small inside but with quaint hometown feel. The serving sizes were huge you could probably feed 2 people off them if you're eating in portions. I had the vegetable omelet it was amazing grilled onions and not fresh cut and the side of potatoes are fresh cut def not out the freezer. Service was pretty quick but this was my first time it got packed by 10 am and there was a small line outside.
author: Carmen L.

description:
It's a local diner and not too many people know about this place. I came here with a friend of mine for a late lunch. He remembered coming here a few years ago and wanted to try out the place again. 

The menu is pretty simple and easy to navigate. I ordered the Glen Park Burger and he ordered a New York Steak with eggs. Overall the food was nothing special but it had a good diner feel to it. I liked eating here because the price was reasonable and there was plenty of seating. The burger was made from ground chuck and even though I ordered it medium well the burger was still tough. They don't serve it on a hamburger bun but on sandwich bread instead. They do have grilled onions in there which adds flavor to the burger. There was something missing in the meal though. I ordered it with a side of fries which are not included with the burger. They were not bad and looked freshly cut and deep fried in oil. 

I would come back for breakfast and give them another shot. They seem like a friendly diner and it's a good place to eat that's close to the Bart station.
author: Tim G.

description: As a breakfast food lover, this place was good! I had the bacon and egg with country potatoes and toast, and it was all very good. Their coffee was amazing. The only reason I gave a 4 was because the service could be better. Other than that, great!
author: Jael M.

description: Great food, loved the spicy Louisiana sausages, huge pancakes were lovely. Family run place, very warming and comforting service. Good prices for the portions you get.
author: Hector S.

description: They only serve regular coffee but they will combine the coffee and hot chocolate to make you a mocha if you ask! Loved it!
author: Laura K.

description:
To quote my husband.."THIS is what a diner should be like". Good prices. Great food. Hot, bottomless mugs of coffee.

We got the breakfast burrito special and the ham and cheese omelette. Both were amazing. 

The service was fast and friendly. We will definitely be back when in the neighborhood.
author: Vanna M.

description:
One word: hot!

Steam coming off all the food: husband' pancakes, coffee, artichoke in my omlete.

I got the special of the day omelet: turkey ham, artichoke, onion, spinach, feta.  

It was very yummy and I recommend this place as your standard diner for breakfast.  It met it's need, nothing super special, nothing especially blah, so I say three stars!
author: Liz K.

description:
I love this place! I always come back whenever I'm in the neighborhood and have the time. Decent price to satisfy a good greasy brunch craving... just what a girl needs every once a while! 

I try to order from their weekly special menu whenever possible. If they have the British Bangers (sausage), GET THAT!!!! I've only seen it twice but oh my god, it's sooo delicious! I think the other ones was the Bockwurst but it wasn't all that spicy (thankfully, for me).

If you want pancakes, you can choose from the weekly batter or the usual butter pancakes. They're very fluffy either way. I usually get the weekly batter...so far I've tried raspberry, blueberry, and banana. As someone who normally doesn't like pancakes and hates bananas, their banana pancakes are the bomb!

As for service, I would have to say 5/5. I'm not exactly introverted but I like to keep to myself and prefer to not make pointless conversation. After my first few initial visits, they recognized me and would let me be. My favorite staff is the shorter waitress. She always remembers to offer me a cup of hot water after I've been seated since I almost always ask for it. Little details like that really make the difference! One quieter, late afternoon, she noticed that I kept looking up at the specials menu and flipping the menu back and forth. She came up to me and asked if she could help. I told her that I couldn't decide between the daily special sausage or the weekly pancake to which she recommended the country style breakfast (consist of 1 egg, 2 short stacks pancake, and sausage). A solution for multiple cravings...!! Yay, thank you Tyger's! Definitely one of my favorite places for brunch within the neighborhood.

*tip: their vegan sausage is...not that good... Throw your healthy habits out of the window and just enjoy the guilty pleasure. :)
author: Jannet H.

description: What a great mix! Kids had french toast and pancakes while my wife and I had chicken Katsu with potatoes and eggs. Beside the quirky menu, this place was fast and  reasonably priced. A great breakfast if you're in the area.
author: Ian H.

description: The food is amazing. Service is good. My mom and I come here on a regular. One of the best little secrets in the city.
author: Lysee H.

description: My husband and I have become weekend regulars here since we moved to the neighborhood about a year and a half ago. Food is consistently delicious and service (on weekends) is fast and friendly! They always remember us and greet us with a smile. Even if there is a line, we've never had to wait more than 10 minutes for a table. Love the pancakes and rotating weekly special of enchiladas and tamales. Cash only, but not a big deal since there is a Wells Fargo ATM about a block away. Avoid going on Monday when the regular staff is not there and service tends to be very slow and not so great. But all other days, it is a winner!
author: Amber H.

description: Went in for a quick lunch the other day to break from the library. I got the California Scramble which was pretty good. One star level for presentation (as it looked like it was literally thrown on the plate) but it tasted like something I would make at home which was what I was looking for. What pissed me off is their totally unstated cash-only policy. Who does cash only at a restaurant and doesn't make it known with a sign or written on the menu or something? The waitress leaves the check on the table super early in the meal, and so I put my card on top of it and wait. And wait. And finally i call her over to let her know I put it down in case she didnt see it and she says "Oh honey wish I could take that but I cant" and then just leaves. Uhhh....ok. Lets just hope I have the cash then, honey. It's not a cheap place for what the food is so I wasn't sure if I would have enough. I ended up having just enough, not including tip so guess what? Look who didnt get tipped! If you want your customers to not feel stupid and angry at your cafe then freaking tell people its cash only!
author: Natalie Y.

description: Food was pretty good, service was okay. Overall it was unmemorable but nice. I was a little worse for the wear after a night of drinking, and the food was just the thing to fix me up.
author: Christopher L.

description: There is nothing more white people like than eggs, toast and some sort of meat for breakfast. We line up for hours for it and it is all the same for some crazy expensive price for what you actually get. This place is no exception. The breakfast served here could be made by a 10 year old. The food is completely lacking of any originality and style. The meat omelette will have two or three small pieces of meat and you can tell they are trying so hard to cut costs wherever they can. Why do people get so excited about this? In addition why do they only accept cash? Oh wait, it's because they are trying to hide their revenue from the IRS and for that reason they will never get a tip from me.
author: Ddc C.

description:
This had become my new lunch place. It is not pretentious or trendy. Two qualifications I look for when venturing out on the weekend.

I always get a tuna melt on sourdough with diet coke. PERFECT! 

Fast service, good food, not too pricey.
author: Julia D.

description:
3.5 stars, but I've rounded up this time because I support family run operations such as this.

It's a cozy little diner nestled in the heart of the Glen Park business district on the corner of Diamond of Chenery.  The small space has tables parked fairly close together so the community inside can eat together and enjoy each other's conversations.  The spot is super popular too so a short wait outside is pretty common.

I came in with four other friends I had just volunteered with at the nearby Glen Canyon Park where we pulled ivy, and dug up radishes, mustard and fennel on a steep, grassy slope.  A park staffer kiddingly noted that we were more effective than a herd of billy goats since we pulled up the unwanted plants with roots and all.  We were tired and hungry but enthusiastic about the work we had just accomplished, and the SF Recs and Park staff we worked alongside of highly recommended the restaurant for small groups.

The menu lists a nice assortment of breakfast dishes alongside burgers and sandwiches.  There is a daily specials board mounted behind the counter but many of the specials (not all) are already printed into the menu.  We all agreed breakfast for lunch (I guess some call it brunch.) would be the preferred choice.  Little glasses of ice water came around to the table.  It took a bit of time before the waiter came back to take our orders.  Very understandable considering how busy this place was.

When the waiter returned I ordered an omelet with turkey sausage, mushroom, onion, avocado and jack cheese.  The omelets come with pan-fried house potatoes and choice of toast.  I had an iced tea to go with my water.  The turnaround time was very fast as we got our food in just a few minutes.  There were so many platters on our little table that we had to jostle everything around to get plates to fit.  My omelet (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/uymg9f_cBIprwMWOqzHGhQ?select=9w-Zgr0TKocW_tyRpGrNNw) was a nice size.  I'm thinking it was probably three eggs.  The generous portion of ingredients sat inside the pocket of the fried egg shell.  The turkey sausage are links cut up into bite sized pieces, and I'm happy to report they give you lots more of the good stuff (avocado) and less of the filler (onion); although, the onions were cooked up soft and I prefer that.  The thinly sliced potatoes were good with nice crispy edges.

The food was a tad on the greasy side, but none of us were complaining as we all ate everything on our plates.  The service is very friendly and very efficient.  In order to get to the small bathroom in the rear you need to go through the kitchen area to get there.  It was quite amazing watching two cooks prepare everything in such a small space.  The bathroom is decent too.  The water in the wash sink was very hot and perfect for scrubbing off all of the dried mud caked on our hands.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: I love love love this place. It's the perfect little neighborhood nook for my weekend breakfast. Every time I eat there I'm so glad that such old school family-run gems still exist in the city. The food is hearty, tasty and always fresh. This is not your typical 'go out for Sunday brunch with mimosas' kind of a joint. It's for the neighborhood and should stay like that :)
author: Tanvi C.

description: Ugh. Glen Park seriously needs a greasy diner, but this place is colon-blow. I'd take just about anything moving into Tyger's at this point. I gave it two stars because the people are nice, but what the food does to my bowels is not nicer than two stars.
author: Melissa M.

description:
OK, so I went in here with my lady and I really wanted to like this place.  The service IS excellent.  The food was REALLY bad. My wife had scrambled eggs with vegetables mixed in, (how hard is that)....  well it tasted like the vegetables had soaked in oil for hours. 

Do yourself a favor  walk across the street to "a nice place to eat" and ENJOY your food.
author: Mister E.

description: Great food!  You'll be satisfied.  Prices have risen a bit but as long ad I'm satisfied I'm fine with it.  Different types of pancakes, like banana, blueberry... they have vegan sausages.  When we go there we have pancakes & omelets.  The cheeseburger with avocados.  What I don't like us when one of the server's tells us "too much food"  We usually get a doggy bag.  Before I finish giving him my order he starts taking my daughter's order.  LOL.  I then tell him "wait I'm not finished.  Other than that I have no complaint.  Mmmm...maybe he's looking out for my girlish figure
author: Dee G.

description: Very poor quality ingredients, and seems expensive for what you get.  Had a Denver Omelette, and the peppers and onions had no flavor, didn't finish it.  Hash browns were OK.  Rye toast was more like Wonder bread.  Sausages tasted like paste, ate one of the four.  I was very hungry going in and still sort of hungry going out, but $20+ poorer.  With tip, well over $20, will not be returning.
author: Ruth F.

description:
This is your typical, neighborhood greasy spoon. I think Yelpers got it right with the cumulative 3.5 star review. It's no frills, not fancy, efficient and everything you would expect from an old-school, traditional diner. Dont get me wrong, there was absolutely nothing wrong with our experience -- it was just average.

Living in the neighborhood, its obvious that its a place where many locals go. It has that throwback, vintage feel which i appreciate. Went early on a Sunday morning (around 8:30) and all tables were filled so we sat at that bar. We got our coffee quickly, the waitress was quick and the food came out as expected.  Nothing about it blew us away. 

We paid, went home and never discussed our meal...which is a sign of mediocrity (in my opinion).

Oh yeah, its CASH ONLY!!!!
author: M. A.

description: My husband and I come here almost every weekend. It seems there aren't any other diners in downtown Glen Park, but this one is pretty good and hits the spot. I like the Roberto's Omelette. My only criticism is that the restaurant could use some renovation, the building it's in is pretty old.
author: amber h.

description: Solid breakfast spot and it isn't too overcrowded. Great food. I do wish they had some hash browns and not just country potatoes--but hey a potato is a potato I guess. Eggs are always great and check out the specials.
author: Won't B.

description: I've eaten here several times and enjoyed all my meals. Love the pancakes. The portions are huge so order accordingly. It tends to get crowded around brunch hours during the weekends. People serving the food are pleasant and welcoming. All in all it's a great local breakfast joint. I'll be a regular here as long as I live the Glen Park area.
author: Pursarth T.

description: This is such a great neighborhood gem. The service is fast and friendly and the fact they have a turkey bacon BLT with avocado just seals the deal for me.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
RAWR.

Tyger's I could just EAT you all up. 

It isn't five star dining but it's certainly satisfying . It's everything you want out of a greasy breakfast and it isn't Denny's or Mel's Diner. Good Bacon, Hot Links, Pancakes, Potatoes, Country Fried Steak and Sausages. 

If you want healthy food, go pick some fruit . Personally, Tyger's is a bit of a guilty pleasure and good for a Nasty Hangover.
author: Hannah A.

description:
Hangover breakfast food!

- Cash only, when our group was doing the whole split-the-bill thing, one of us had to go over to the B of A ATM a block away because we were short. 

- Generally large portions. The five of us each ordered something, and the table was filled corner to corner with plates!

- Funny waitress lady. After giving our orders, one of us decided he wanted more, so he asked, "Can I get a side of french toast" and she says, "Nooo" in this knowing tone, "it's a lot of food!". Hahah we all cracked up, nothing like a middle-aged asian lady telling you what to do! :) Turns out we had ordered more than enough food and probably couldn't have finished the extra french toast :P

- Food itself is nothing to die for, just your standard eggs and pancakes and such.

- Parking was metered on Diamond St. We were in and out in an hour.

- A little grungy on the inside in the "neighborhood diner" kind of way
author: Suejung S.

description: I came here for breakfast during my last visit to San Francisco. I had a cheese and ham sandwich toasted, which tasted good. The service was also good, can't really say much more than that.
author: Matt B.

description: What a great place.  Visiting in the area from L.A. Looking for breakfast near my favorite bookstore - Bird & Beckett (what a GREAT neighborhood!). The breakfast at the counter on Saturday morning was perfect, the Tyger scramble? Omlet? Don't remember but the veggies were fresh and lightly cooked and all was hot and well served. Just loved it. Oh, and quite reasonable for so much food!
author: Laurie P.

description: My boyfriend and I like to have breakfast here weekend mornings. The place is small, but that's not a deal breaker. The food is mediocre, but refills on coffee are free. Huge plus. I need me my coffee. The service was good and they're very friendly. I'm all for mom and pop kinda places like this.
author: Rachel A.

description:
I've never posted before, but my meal this morning inspired me to write a quick review of this place.

I like the old-fashioned neighborhood diner feel, despite the fact the food is mediocre. I ordered some oatmeal this morning and a fried egg. Egg should have been fried medium and instead the yolk was entirely uncooked. Oatmeal was bad. Clearly their instant oatmeal was stale. It had a bad "off" taste to it.

Okay, this is not a huge deal to me, actually. I just didn't eat the oatmeal and dealt with the runny egg.

But when they came to clear my table and asked about the uneaten oatmeal, the fellow looked concerned, but not for me. Next the owner/waitress comes over and starts to argue with me that it's fresh and they make each batch as it's ordered--which I must say isn't that tough to do when dealing with instant. I reply that I'm not trying to argue. She says that no one's every complained and she's been there 30 years, to which I reply that there is a first for everything.

And yes, I do end up paying nearly $5 for a bowl of uneaten, stale oatmeal that cost them maybe .50 cents.

So, like I said, I know this isn't a gourmet place and I'm fine with that. But some semblance of civility and concern over a bad dish would be appreciated.
author: David Z.

description:
I liked this place. Feels like the place has been around for a very long time although I can't find any history on the place yet. I got the country fried steak. Delicious if you can afford the calories. 
Coffee was standard dinner style. 
We had a great seat at the window that looks down Diamond.
author: Jeff H.

description: The pancakes here are the best.  The omelettes and other stuff is good too.  They have cool stuff that other places dont on their menu.  Since the Village grill in west portal closed I currently rank this as #1 breakfast diner in town.
author: Petey F.

description:
This is one of those great home-y diners that reminds me of my mom and dad's old diner. It makes me feel so at home =) 

Food-wise  they have all your typical american diner breakfast stuff from blueberry pancakes (DeLISH!), omelets, french toast, and various other egg dishes. 

I had the turkey sausage omelets - it was very good with big bits of turkey sausage interspersed. it was also served with toast and homefries. My friend had the blueberry pancakes along with accompanied eggs and bacon - very filling and satisfying.

Overall, the food is obviously nothing out of the ordinary, but I just love that longstanding diner feel where everything is pretty good, greasy, and friendly. I picture coming back on a sunday afternoon in need of some comfort food.
author: Tim B.

description: Food was okay, nestled in Glen Park a cool breakfast spot. nothing you can't make at home. only issue i had was it was wayyyy to loud in there.
author: Tiff W.

description:
i like to go to here for various reasons including reasons not already listed below

i enjoy the service and also i like the location and also i like potatoes and breakfast meats which are served here
author: Andy W.

description:
Before we had set out on a long drive out to Monterey Bay, my friend took me to a small diner nearby his place. The place isn't glitz or glamoured, but has a nice warm homey atmosphere to it.  Upon entrance, I was greeted by a small framed Asian female with a big friendly smile that just lit up the place. 

I would recommend ordering a plate that is served with the sausage. Slightly seasoned with a hint of cumin & spices, the sausage has a nice light spicy flavor with each bite. 

Aside from attentive and friendly customer service, and hearty portions, I just love the warmth of the diner. It was a definitely a great place to momentarily escape from the fast pace of the city.
author: Vicki T.

description:
I regularly walk by Tyger's and it's almost always packed because it's the only "real" coffee shop that serves a full breakfast in Glen Park. 

 IMHO, food quality is just ok.  Comparable to any other diner type coffee shop I've ever been to, including Denny's. The prices are a bit high -- $8-10 -- but the servings are large (which justifies the prices) and the service is quick and attentive despite how busy they are. 

I had the pancake/egg/meat combo recently and the pancakes were so huge that I couldn't finish them.  Coffee and water are promptly refilled w/and w/o request.  

A great place to have breakfast if you're in the area.
author: Martin C.

description:
I have been coming to this breakfast spot since I was a little girl.  I now call it one of my neighborhood gems.  During the week there is generally no wait.  On the weekends, it is often another story and the wait can be awhile.  The portions are large and filling.  I love everything, the pancakes, jumbo raisin walnut french toast, or eggs and bacon (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=GIMg5oHqsJXdRq_7tR2jjQ).  I have, however, had better home fries and the lunch doesn't really do it for me.  I also think it is weird that you have to get French Fries on the side, but they aren't good for you anyway so whateves.  

Come for breakfast.  The service is good and the food hits the spot.
author: Justine D.

description: This Place Is Awful. When You Walk In, You Can Tell The Place is Dirty. The Walls and Windows Need To Be Cleaned. The Service Is Prompt But Over Priced. My Mom Ordered One Pancaked, One Sausage, And Two Eggs. The Waiter Messed Up The Ordered And Charged Almost Double. I Ordered The Chenery Scramble, It was Tasteless, Needed Salt, Th Onions Were Cut Way To Big. The So called Country Potatoes Were semi Mashed and Sliced, Not Cubed, And They Had NO SALT, NO FLAVOR. I Do Not Recommend This Place, Go Across The Street For A Better Experience.
author: Susana R.

description: Yum! Had the pancake sandwich cuz the reviews said pancakes were good. And they were. Prices were reasonable too. Long time friend said this place was good and she had been going here for many years. People are very friendly. What more do u want in a restaurant?!
author: Sandra L.

description:
Great service. Great food. And great coffee. Highly recommended.

The staff is friendly and helpful. 

Please note that they only take cash.
author: Fred T.

description: A friend suggested this place since we wanted to grab breakfast nearby & weren't too familiar with the city. This place is pretty fun-sized & it was pretty packed, but we got seated quickly. I got the french toast w/ ham & easy over eggs. It was good, nothing outta this world that would make me want to really come back..but we left satisfied after a long night of partying :)
author: Elise T.

description:
Cozy corner diner in Glen Park. I found myself a table by the window and sat by myself when I was approached by (what I believe to be) the owner's son. I asked him about the tea selection and he turned and the first thing out of his mouth was "mom." How often do you run into that nowadays?

I ordered the california scramble, two eggs scrambled with avocado, mushrooms, and tomatoes. With Stash Green Tea (so glad that it wasn't Celestial Seasonings tea) and a side of turkey bacon. No toast.

The scramble: not the best in presentation...I know, I know. I am in a DINER so let's say it's "diner scramble" quality. I didn't know the scramble came with a side of home fries too, which were thinly sliced. Yum. The 4 turkey bacon strips were crispy.

Attentive service.

Make sure to stake out a window table (there are 2 two-tops and 2 four-tops along the window) for people watching. :)
author: Ileana H.

description: I love this place. There's nothing fancy about it, but it can't be beat for a simple breakfast and coffee.
author: Michael S.

description:
Not a bad place for breakfast. There are a number of breakfast options in this part of Glen Park, but this is one of the better. The coffee was not the best I've had -- far from it, actually. The eggs were decent, and the bacon and hash browns were very good.

Tyger's is easy to get to from the Glen Park BART or from any of the houses nearby, if you live there. Definitely worth checking out.
author: David H.

description:
I get coffee down the block daily, sometimes twice a week.
I must have walked by at least a million times (understatement).
Why I passed up on this cute diner so many times will remain a quandary (especially with my preference for diner food) but I'm glad I finally paid Tyger's Cafe a visit. 

In short, I am always happy when I can get breakfast, namely omelettes, any time of the day. I like the way the eggs are cooked here, they aren't overcooked and dry like most places. They have a "unique" jumbo walnut french toast that sounds divine, which I have yet to try. Will be back! Whatever coffee they serve is outstanding since I can drink cups on end... I'm sure I almost consumed an entire pot in one visit. 

Overall I am impressed and satisfied every time I eat here.
author: Annie L.

description: I have been coming here for a few years. A very good neighbor diner. The specials are always good. Corned beef hash is made from real corned beef and not canned. Everyone is treated special. Prices are fair. There is plenty to chose from on the menu. The omelets are cooked perfectly. I like coming here for Sunday breakfast, i am rarely disappointed in the food or service.
author: Janet C.

description:
This place is awesome. I've been here more than a few times, but thought it deserved a proper rating. 

The location is fantastic, but given the popularity of this place, it is just way too small for the number of apparently loyal clientele that visit here...some on a more than once a day basis. 

I have tried a lot of their items off their menu, but I'm always a fan of going with what the regulars are eating and/or what seems to be the item that most people are eating. 

The item that inspired me to write this review today was the corned beef and hash. Admittedly, I just came from running 1/2 of the SF marathon so any food would have been welcome, but an order of corned beef hash, eggs over easy and and two slices of sourdough was the ticket. 

The wait staff is pretty busy running around trying to get everyone seated, ordered and eating as quickly as they can. 

The two man cooking crew in the back is obviously busy pushing out orders and of course the two busy "boys" are just as frantic turn tables for the next group. 

The corned beef hash was excellent. Definitely not from a can and I've been to my fair share of places where stuff is obviously from a can or an amalgamation of components from different cans. I regret not asking for it to be cooked a little longer, maybe a deeper char on the outside to get more crusty goodness. Oh well, no loss here. 

The eggs oozed their yellow goodness over the top and with a squeeze of the Heinz ketchup (aka condiment ambrosia aka the condiment of the gods) and some crystal or Ashburn hot sauce and the meal is complete. 

It actually hurt to eat, because of the run, but i inhaled that thing.... it is awesome... you have to get it.... but make sure you choose the right weekend as it is only every other weekend. 

p.s. - they have an eggs benedict and a pumpkin pancake which also is awesome, even if you can't use condiment ambrosia on pancakes...or can you?
author: Andrew C.

description:
I love Tyger's for my weekend breakfast. There's never much of a line, and when there is, it moves quick. They offer all the usual breakfast staples, plus a board full of delicious specials. My favorite is the every-other-weekend eggs benedict. I get it with the vegan sausage and it sure is yummy! The buckwheat pancakes are mighty fine, too.

This is very much a Glen Park neighborhood favorite and with the good food, and quick and friendly service, it's no wonder.
author: Kenny H.

description:
I think I would actually give them an 3.5 if I could, which I think matches their average. I have only ever been here for breakfast, but I really enjoyed my omelette. It was something of a fat-bomb (my fault for ordering the deliciousness of bacon, sour cream, and avocado.)

The drawback is really the not-very-nice bathroom (so if you are picky about such things, don't pay it a visit.) I am normally open to a wide variety of sketchy bathroom situations, but even I declined to use this one.
author: Dena D.

description: One of my favorite spots for breakfast. I always order a cheese, bacon, and mushroom. Pancakes are good too. They only make homefries; I think hashbrowns would be better, that's the only thing I'd change. Service is good here, family owned.  Can't go wrong here.
author: Michael L.

description: Tyger's coffee shop is just what it's name says. It's a great old school family friendly (read: can have some noise) joint. If you're looking for a slightly fancy take on traditional American breakfast fare, then try Toast Eatery or, for a very fancy take with fancier surroundings) then consider Savor in Noe valley. But if a straightforward yet delicious omelette, pancake, French toast, etc with lots of refills on fresh brewed coffee (decaf available but don't expect a cappuccino), then look no further. I've been there over 20 times and the smiles as well as the food from the friendly staff are very consistent. Oh, and my breakfast companion is impressed by their poached eggs. 5 stars. Cash only.
author: E K.

description: Came here today for my friends bday because it had pretty decent reviews. We ordered banana pancakes, an omelette, and sausage with eggs. The food took 15 minutes to come and it was good. typical breakfast food that is yummy and satisfying and also a GREAT PRICE! The woman there is also very friendly and super bubbly and happy. Will definitely go there again.
author: Katie C.

description:
I have nothing but great respect for the letter "Y."  After all, my name starts with it.  However, as it was the case in that Will Smith movie, The Pursuit of Happyness, the letter Y in the name of this diner seems to be accidental.  Since I don't go to dyners . . . umm, sorry, I mean diners . . . to learn spelling, I think it might be time to move on.

I stopped by last Thursday morning, and the place was buzzing.  I found a tiny table by the window and sat down.  It took me a second to flag down the waitress/cashier/owner (?) but I didn't mind one bit.  It's not like she was sitting around filing her nails in the corner.  She was running around, bringing food, taking orders, cleaning tables and ringing customers up.

While I waited for her to notice me, I had a chance to look around.  The wood paneling screamed 1980s, as did the lithographs on the walls.  The specials written in dry erase marker on the white board, on the other hand, screamed 2010.  What the hell is "quinoa?"  Do I want it in my soup?  Wikipedia on the iPhone to the rescue . . .

I ordered the basic diner breakfast fare: 2 pancakes, ham, scrambled eggs and a side of wheat toast.  Don't judge.  The pancakes came on a separate plate, and they were absolutely humongous.  They were very fluffy, although they seemed to have too much canola oil in them.  Either that, or the canola oil was extra pungent.  Eek.  The eggs were fresh and fluffy as well.  The slice of ham, although small, was delicious.  

The place is really old school: there is no sugar free syrup or Splenda.  If you care about things like that, bring your own.  The maple syrup is on the table before the pancakes, just like Rainman would have liked.  Serving it in old honey bear-shaped bottles is a nice touch.  The little packets of jam were on the table, too.

Word of advice: drive 200 feet up Diamond Street and park for free.  There's no need to pay 25 cents for 7.5 minutes of parking at the meter, or whatever they charge you these days.  Don't give Gavin Newsom the satisfaction.

I live very close by, and I will be back with my own Splenda looking for parking on Diamond Street.  See you there?
author: Yan G.

description: My new favorite breakfast spot!!! Banana pancakes were to die for, servings are HUGE!!!! And the apple juice is the real deal!!!
author: Kristine S.

description:
I go here quite often, I've tried many of their dishes and they were awful, I wouldn't order them again.

I only go here for the OMELETTES ! (Bacon, Avocado, and Sour cream). I'd say it's a good breakfast spot, but consider other restaurants in the neighborhood for lunch.
author: Brigida W.

description: This place may look a little intimidating from the outside, but once you get inside, it is the best greasy spoon I have ever tried. The service is great, very friendly people, the atmosphere is nice and comfortable, and the food is exactly the hearty, delicious goodness you would expect.
author: Chris H.

description: SUPER greasy spoon. Huge portions. Really sweet service.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
Stephen and I love this neighborhood and have wanted to try what looked like an old school diner.  There are often people waiting in line.  Usually a good sign.  We finally made it there today.  What a let down.

We were seated right away and liked the family style help.  There!  Two stars so far. . . yeah!

But the food?  Yuck.

Stephen had the jumbo walnut raisin french toast.  Undercooked.  Undergood.  They want you to use the syrup on the table served in honey bears.  I doubt its maple - tasted watered down and couldn't hide the bleh taste of what is usually a no-brainer yummy thing to get.

I made a huge mistake in ordering the chicken enchiladas and eggs.  By enchiladads, they served up what tasted like chicken chili rolled in tortillas with Pace Picante salsa on top.  Seriously.  Eggs were fluffy and pretty good.  Potatoes were the blandest thing I've ever tasted.  The best part was the wheat taste on the side.  

Sorry, cute-ish, old-school, family-run neighborhood diner.  I wanted to like you so much but the food was just this side of yucky.  :(
author: Michelle C.

description: Found in this place on a fluke and came back the very next weekend. It's a simple cafe with a great selection. The owners and staff were really nice and attentive. Loved the french toast and the country fried steak. Cash only but most small cafes are. The prices are very reasonable so it doesn't bother me and portions are big. Win win.
author: Nicole H.

description: Been here a few times and it's really not very good. Pancakes from shopbought batter, OJ from a bottle, the meat is not very good quality - and nothing is particularly tasty or well cooked.
author: Pia C.

description: I am a big fan of well-made pancakes and this place does it right. Big, fluffy and the blueberry ones are stuffed with blueberries. A bit pricey for a place with a hole-in-the-wall vibe, but pancakes are worth it!
author: Rich P.

description: Very nice neighborhood restaurant. I had the Ham & Cheese omelette and got a side of sausage gravy to pour on my potatoes. I was very satisfied when I left and would definatly go back. Good service.  It's not a huge place so probably not good for big parties. You can tell lot's of locals which is usually a good sign of repeat customers.
author: Tim H.

description:
Their pancakes are absolutely otherworldly. Thick, rich, moist and flavorful. Best I've had in a long time.
Kudos also due for the warm Korean hospitality.
author: Joe S.

description: BIGGEST PANCAKE I EVER SEEN! Oooof, I'm full. Yummy. Coffee's the worst of all mankind there, BYOC (Bring your own coffee). There are few place you can get coffee before arriving at Tyger's to get their killer Pancake!  Note: just get the pancake, not the combo deal because you won't be able to finish'em all.
author: Pepe W.

description: The best diner feeling hometown ambiance. Never that long of a wait for weekend brunch. The pumpkin pancakes were intense. Cash only.
author: Aaron H.

description:
This is a breakfast/lunch spot. Nothing fancy about it but the staff make this place run like a machine. This is like the 60's version of the chain Toast. From the great tasting pancakes to the bottom less hot coffee this place is on my top list of places to go for breakfast. 

Their menu is not complex and their meals are basic (omelets, eggs, burgers and club sandwiches). For instance if you ask for steal cut oatmeal they might not have any idea what you are talking about. But that is okay! This is a fresh experiance to the typical over trendy breakfast places of San Fran.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Tyger's isn't one of those posh restaurants with pretty decors and sleek furniture. But who cares, right? As long as it's clean and the food's good, that's all what matters!

My friend and I came down here after taking our JEPET exam at SFSU because we neglected to eat breakfast before the test. I thought parking would be hard to find but it really wasn't. If you guys are looking for parking at Glen Park and you didn't know yet, there's a public parking lot right in front of the Bart station. I think the limit's 5 hours. Just saying...lol

Anyways, the food, as I said, is pretty good. Tyger's can beat Denny's and iHop's asses anytime! Pancakes are the fluffiest, even fluffier than iHop! International House of Pancakes my ass! I love their toast and sausages too! I had a taste of my friend's spicy cajun sausages -- perrffeeecctt! I suggest you try it sometime too =]

The only thing I kinda didn't like is the space isn't big enough to accommodate big groups. So yea, I don't recommend taking your whole family (including aunties and uncles and cousins and grandparents) to have breakfast here. It's ideal if you bring 1-2 people. But other than that, you might have to wait a while to get seated.

All in all, I'm definitely coming back! Yay!
author: Michelle B.

description:
I checked out Tyger's the other day during lunch and went for their breakfast. I've never really been into breakfast places because my dad makes just as good or even better breakfasts.

The scene:

It's a quaint little coffee shop with limited seating. There was a huge wait out the door when we arrived, but they were able to sit us quickly.

The food:

Our group got the Raspberry Pancakes, Louisiana Hot Sausage and Eggs, Country Fried Steak, Pastrami On Rye Sandwich and the Tyger Special (turkey and bacon sandwich). I, myself, had the pancakes, but I was able to steal a bite of the hot sausages and the country fried steak, and boy, they were good!

Raspberry Pancakes - These chewy and thick pancakes are made with a raspberry puree batter. With each bite, I could see chunks of raspberry in the pancake. I'm always curious to know how you make chewy pancakes! I must find the secret.
author: Sam L.

description:
Any place that serves buckwheat pancakes is usually a hit with me! I shared a short stack with my friend to needlessly supplement our already large breakfasts. 

The home fries are ok, I wished they were a little crispier. The French fries I saw on other people's plates looked good so maybe those next time instead. My eggs were done just like I like 'em and the bacon was great. Firm yet chewy and not overly greasy but a little overly salty. My friend, however, described his ham n' jack omelette as "basic." 

I'll be back for more of those buckwheat pancakes for sure at this totally old school diner.  ....  I think its still 1962 in there.
author: Jeff P.

description: Pretty solid breaky-break. A little pricey, but thats SF breakfast for ya.
author: schmoo l.

description:
*The Experience*:
I really love this place! The staff here are so sweet and are always happy to see new people and the regulars. They make sure to greet you and make sure to let you know they'll be with you in a minute (if they haven't already seen to you!).
