Whenever people are in this neck of the woods and are hankering for some good ole' fashion American (well, Californian American) breakfast, I make sure to suggest Tyger's and try to get my friends to go there. 
    The ambiance is straight-up, no frills, tables-and-chairs. I've never been there when it hasn't been empty, so I usually eat with the chatter and the normal noises of families with small children, families with older grandparents, young people, old people, all types of people! I'm glad there is a place like Tyger's to show people that not all eating establishments in SF are full of hipsters, bougie techies/i-bankers, huppies (hippy+yuppie), faux-homeians (fake bohemians), and earth-mother breeders. You'll find that all are welcome at Tyger's and the staff will make sure that you feel that way.

*The Food*:
Again, straight-up, good ole' fashion breakfast items. I agree with others that the coffee is a bit weak, but it'll do if you need your caffeine fix. I've had the pancakes, scrambles, omelettes, and the sides of bacon and hash browns. Seriously, the food hits-the-spot. For some, the food would just be a-ok...perhaps a step-up from Denny's/IHOP, but not as good as other SF breakfast establishments. As for me, I'm a 'Yay! I'm a fan' and give a 4-star rating because Tyger's fits the bill of a breakfast place that serves the kind of no-frills breakfast you remember growing up in your small suburban town (but, in my case, Tyger's is  way better since my suburban town was a hell-hole, and SF has fresher ingredients).   

*Would I Eat Here Again?*:
Hell to the Yea. I can't get here as often as I like because I am not up early enough to eat breakfast. But like I said, if friends want to meet up to have breakfast in Glen Park, then I have no qualms in recommending Tyger's and secretly hope that we can decide on Tyger's as it's so convenient to get to (a block from Glen Park Bart Station), the great and welcoming staff, and the hits-the-spot kind of breakfast food.
author: Patricia S.

description:
Still the best place for breakfast.  Best coffeeshop coffee anywhere and yah it ain't cheap but neither is Starsucks or Martha and Bros.(that's where I buy bulk coffee).

This is definitely Pancake, corned beef, and omelet city!
author: Charlie A.

description: My friends took me for a late breakfast at Tyger's.  When we got there afternoon, it was not busy at all.  So, we have no problem getting a table right away.  Nice homey diner feeling.  Waitress was attentive.  The prices on the menu is decent.  Portion for our food was more than enough. =) We shared a banana pancake. I must say it is delics!  However, for my own plate, The California Scramble with potatoes.. it was somewhat too oily for me... But i was hungry, so i finished all my eggs anyway. But overall, it's a nice place to go and get together with friends.  Parking could be hard to look for if it's peak hours. On Wednesday, there was constructions going on.. so there was a lot of parking spaces N/A... .
author: Selina L.

description:
Food-Good
Service-Very friendly
Atmosphere-Crowded, noisy, warm and cozy
Drawback-It's "Cash Only" but there are NO signs posted to indicate this, so after a good food-induced coma, one must lug his/her self to a nearby bank to withdraw cash.
author: Suna M.

description: I went here because some people I was with said it was the best.  We were seated right away and our food came quickly. I was starving and ordered the tuna melt and the french onion soup. The tune melt was almost decent. Pretty dry, kind of a weird color and I think they put carrots in it. It was no where near cheesy enough. The soup was downright terrible. The "crouton" might as well have been a piece of cardboard set on top (it was so terrible it might have really been cardboard) with a little pile of cheese on top. The soup itself was pretty flavorless. Normally, when I'm as hungry as I was, anything and everything tastes pretty good. But even this food was still lousy.
author: mel m.

description:
I just got back from a great breakfast here! 

--Big portions!
--Truly fresh-squeezed orange juice!
--My pancakes and sausage were above average but pretty standard.
--My over-easy egg was cooked PERFECTLY. Best-cooked egg I've had in years.
--The boyfriend had the buckwheat pancakes, which he didn't seem thrilled about (never had that kind before) but I would have traded for them. They were great.

The service was friendly and efficient. We sat at the counter and I could see the goings-on in the kitchen.

This is very clearly a beloved neighborhood joint; it really adds to the delightful small, home-town feel of Glen Park. If I lived near here I can imagine coming back often. As it is, it isn't *quite* special enough to go out of my way to return, but that's the only thing stopping me.
author: Lynae Z.

description:
This place has been around a LONG time.  It's your standard greasy spoon, hangover breakfast.  During the weekend, it's insanely busy, and you will wait a while for a table.  I usually sit at the counter, and have my eggs and breakfast meat.

People seem to know everybody here, and there are plenty of daily regulars.  You won't find anything too special here over anyplace else.  There are daily specials which seem pretty good.

Stop by if you are in the neighborhood!
author: Michael M.

description:
File this in the "overlooked for way too long" category.  In fact, I should really just go and Yelp every last restaurant in Glen Park--there's only what, like 3 more?

Granted, Higher Grounds provides such a killer breakfast fix that it left my curiosity satiated, and I never bothered to trek across the street to Tyger's.  The very nonchalant facade and difficulty of seeing inside don't help either.  So, the verdict?  First, be prepared to wait outside in the cold, but take heart that the line moves fairly quickly (our total wait on Sunday at noon was about 15 minutes).  A lot of reviewers call this a "diner", but there's no bright color scheme, no booths, no waitresses in pink outfits.  I tend to think of it as a "neighborhood breakfast joint" instead...you can really feel that the locals jealously guard this place as their own.  Very much like Breakfast at Tiffany's in Portola, only with fewer crayon drawings and better food.  French toast with walnuts?  Old-school but scrumptious.  Omelettes?  Enormous.  Veggie sausages?  Available.  'Nuff said.
author: Wes M.

description:
Tyger's needs a better fume hood, because inevitably you'll come out of breakfast there smelling like a greasy spoon. Which isn't entirely inappropriate, considering that's exactly what it is. 

I have a friend who waitressed at Tyger's during the Unemployment Bonanza of 2002-3, and there's something about Tyger's that lends itself to that archetypal tired diner waitress brushing the hair out of her eyes, sighing while picking up yet another coffee pot off the Bunn warmer and calling you "hon" and "darlin." Not that my friend was like that, just that it's that kind of place. It's also the kind of place that makes Glen Park such a neighborhood. There's a wall of pictures of neighborhood kids, and when a neighbor is down on their luck, they can earn tips slinging french toast to all the neighbors who show up faithfully on weekend mornings to bask in the bacon smoke.

Well, that may be romanticizing it a bit. And by a bit I mean totally ridiculous. But you know what I mean. It's a diner. Greasy decent food. Cute neighborhood. The end.
author: Megan W.

description:
I've heard many a story about this place.  I went today with a friend for breakfast.  We were quickly seated, and I ordered the chicken chimichanga and eggs and my friend got the beef tamales and eggs.
Pretty standard stuff.  I had no idea what a chimichanga was, and my friend pretty much summed it up as soon as the plates arrived at the table.
"Frozen burritos."
Spot on description.  
Anyway, the food was pretty bland and kind of overpriced for what it was.  The beef tamales were pretty haggard looking.  The staff seemed friendly but we were ignored for awhile when we wanted refills.  However, they had Dr. Pepper!  This was exciting because I love Dr. Pepper.
author: Meh M.

description:
Slinging a FIVE with pride I am. 

1 Star = One word, rib-sticking-down-home-good-greasy-delights
1 Star = Staff that remembers you and even if they don't they do a damn good job of faking it.
1 Star = Homey local feel, in fact if you are not from the Glen Park/Sunnyside i think you get charged some kind of tourist tax.
1 Star = Because some things are totally worth the wait.
1 Star = Bear shaped syrup bottles, real sour cream and did we mention the hash browns?  My my my, I think I need a moment!
author: Bruce R.

description:
I love Tygers!  Tygers is one of those places you don't see anymore being created anymore.  Down home good cooking.  Today it seems everyone wants to be the new posh restaurant.  With their sleek designs, modern furniture, down tempo lounge music, and trendy wait staff that people forget there were alternatives. Simpler places.  Diners.

Tygers is great.  The wait staff there works frantically and efficiently to keep the customers happy.  Granted this isn't your fancy restaurant but man the brunch food is good.  The diner coffee is great.  The service is wonderful.  It is a perfect place to have a nice Sunday brunch at, and I often do.

Country Breakfast here I come!
author: Dave S.

description:
I get headaches eating here.
Always a loud clatter, the service is always rushed and rude (whether is is bustling as usual or empty) and the price indeed can be beat.
But the cook is great!
Excellent American diner food.
Here's my best guess - the cook met the server in Vietnam or Indonesia and moved out here to open up the restaurant.
He must have been a cook in the service, no one else knows how to prepare such delicious food without much butter.
It seems to be his dream - Tyger's, while it seems to be simply her life.
Maybe I'm building a narrative around limited exposure, maybe I'm insightful.
These conclusions I've drawn don't change with any visit though.
If the waitress was nicer, I'd ask her about it.
I never get that chance.
SO - great food - terrible service.
I kinda love it.
author: Theo R.

description:
Reliably solid breakfast food. The friendly staff always sculpt a little happy face on my nephew's pancakes, and the vegetarian fake sausage is a peppery delight.  

I wish it weren't cash only though.
author: angela n.

description:
I love Tyger's! When I moved to SF 14 years ago I live in Glen Park briefly and would stop by this diner in the morning to carb up before risking my life on BART. My old favorites are the chimmichanga's and the spicy sausage. Eggs are always done right (over medium). Always get the sourdough toast.  The ladies that server up this goodness are top notch and super friendly.

Tyger's may not be right for those of you with refined tastes. And anyone who has watched Glen Park change over the years knows that the neighborhood has become more 'refined'? There's a French restaurant caddy corner to Tyger's for goodness sakes! That place used to be a dive bar. The Canyon market? That was a Middle Eastern grocery store many years ago - with parking! Anyway, I'm way off track here.

Tyger's is a slice of that old Glenn Park...the one that introduced me to San Francisco living many years ago. 

These days I'll visit Tyger's once or twice a year. One thing that I always look forward to (besides the chimmichanga's) is seeing the ladies who have been serving goodness for all these years. They never cease to please me when they see me walking in and give me that flash of recognition and greet me like I've been going there 3 times a week for 14 years.

I love this place.
author: C K.

description:
Tyger's needs, um better food?  
Me: My french toast is burnt. 
Waiter: No it's not, thats' just how it is. 
Me: Thats' burnt, and it doesn't taste right please fix it. 
Waiter: fine. but that not burnt okay i fix for you. but you no complain.
?!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!(1)One extra point for the laugh but I mean its either the food or the service I can't decide.
author: fuck you p.

description:
Delicious, hearty and very reasonably priced traditional breakfast fare at this mom and pop coffee shop in Glen Park. 

Check out their (?) wacky website: http://www.tygerscoffeeshop.com/corp/mission/
author: Trinh T.

description:
I love diners.  I love diner food.  Tyger's is a perfect diner.  Big portions and the breakfast is generous and delicioso.  The place is old and looks it....it has the same kind of presswood paneling that my abuelita's kitchen had (and still does...abuelito refuses to remove it).  Perhaps that's why I feel at home here.

I'll warn you, if you're AT ALL prissy, you may be offended by these shaggy-looking premises.  But then again, if you're prissy, you probably spend a lot of time being offended.
author: Randy F.

description: The best neighborhood diner! Be prepared to wait in queue outside on weekends. Great specials written on the white board changes daily. Awesome pancakes and home made corned beef!
author: Kelly B.

description:
This is a really tasty breakfast spot, but it's far from perfect.  The highlights are the pancakes and the bacon, which are both delicious.  However, their omelets / scrambles and potatoes leave a LOT to be desired.  If they changed their recipes for those, I could bump them up a star or two.

I used to go here a lot when I first moved to the Glen Park area, but I've since started going to Toast and Chloe's in southern Noe Valley, as I think their menus are a little bit more well-rounded.  Still, you can certainly do worse than Tyger's.  Be prepared to wait in a line on the weekends, though.
author: Chad H.

description:
When my roommate and I first moved to Glen Park, we were always lamenting everything 'the old neighborhood' had that we would never see again *sooo dramatic, lol*.  One of those places was Eddy's cafe on Divisidero.

Last week we decided to have brunch together and tried Tyger's.  As soon as we walked in I pointed out excitedly that it reminded me of Eddy's.  The food was great although I wasn't too keen on the vegan sausage-but with enough ketchup anything tastes good.

The ambiance was cozy and friendly and the wait staff were attentive.  I would highly recommend this place, and it's right off of BART too!
author: Lily E.

description:
Yelp, it's been a while since I've written a review - so I'm firing off another quick one to continue my reviews about breakfast places (going to do one or two more of these - sadly, I haven't been diligent about eating breakfast lately).

I'm charmed by this diner - generous portions of good food at a reasonable price.  Plus, it's a cozy setting with very friendly service.  As I've been living in Glen Park for the last few months, it's comforting to know that this place is nearby for French Toast, eggs, and bacon.
author: Eddie A.

description: Pancakes A+++. Prices good. Very clean.  One of the places where you have to walk through the kitchen to get to the restroom. Very cool place. A little quaint and funky. Close to Candlestick.
author: Tom O.

description:
Pros: Great prices for breakfast, Generous portions
Cons: Service is a bit slow, can be crowded, feels like a cafeteria rather a diner. 

Overall: I will definitely eat here again, but in the quest for affordable delicious breakfast, this local fav falls short in my book.
author: Philip H.

description:
Glen Park is a different place from when I moved there eleven years ago.  Back then it was definitely an old school neighborhood.  Some things have changed for the better or worse but my breakfast standby has thankfully made it through the years.

Thanks Tyger's-- don't ever change.
author: SaraMitra P.

description:
Love this little neighborhood gem for a weekend brunch.

Terrific Turkey Italian Sausage -- a bit spicy, but delicious!

Only negative about this joint -- cash only. So come with cash.
author: Gil Z.

description: This is my second time here and I'd keep coming back. It's a great breakfast/brunch diner in Glen Park. Good food, good service, and cheap. Their specials are really good and are posted on the whiteboard. Hasn't disappointed yet, and the bonus is I saw SF's current poet laureate whom my girlfriend did a research project on last month!
author: Lyndon M.

description:
This is the diner equivalent of Cheers.  Everybody knows your name.  Friendly and full of neighbors--regulars.  Not only will they remember what you like and how you like it, they will put your drink on a table when they see you crossing the street.  

Diner menu.  I have found some things I like here, and stick with 'em.  Burgers, bbq burger especially, garden burger, tuna melt, BLT, club or turkey sandwich w potato salad or chips.....my favorites.  Good coffee/tea.  

It's just a good-feeling place to be!
author: Ellen S.

description: I've lived in the neighborhood for over fifteen years and been to Tyger's maybe four times. The last visit was in January 2014. I'm always surprised at how mediocre the food has consistently remained. The quality of the food reflects the attitude of the management . . . why make improvement when business is steady? My recommendation: If you' re too hungry to get in your car or hop on your bike and go elsewhere, Tyger's is an appropriate choice. One thing that is entertaining is the Asian women who runs the restaurant who is truly the "Tyger Mom" with her customers as undeserving children. For those of you who like neglect and are familiar with indifference then go to Tyger's to get your familiar dose of invalidation. If you want to raise the bar and find a great place for food in a setting that actually attempts to make your experience memorable, go elsewhere.
author: Charlie T.

description:
I have wanted to try Tygers for...years, really, and finally made it over today about 1:30 p.m.  It was packed...Sunday afternoon, I guess...but husband and I were greeted and treated to a table by the window.  So far, so good.  It was smaller inside that I had imagined and no booths...still...hoping for a pleasant experience.  I ordered the shrimp salad and hubby the BLT&A, his usual no matter where we go.

There was a long wait to be served, but I'm used to that and can deal.  My shrimp, however, were FROZEN.  There were a liberal amount on some lettuce, a hard-boiled egg, pale tomatoes.  I couldn't quite get over the frozen seafood.  No one came back to the table to inquire, so I just picked around the salad and tried to "thaw out" the shrimp with friction from my fork.  Not fun.  The BLT&A got good reviews, although he said it needed more mayo...but that is a personal taste.

Might come back for breakfast, but no more shrimp salads for me, that's for sure.  Sorely disappointed.
author: Susan V.

description:
Every neighborhood needs a corner coffee shop, this one needs a remodel.  Its always crowded, especially on the weekends for breakfast but my gut feeling is it is convienient rather than beloved.  

Thumbs UP: Glen Park's only classic breakfast joint 
Thumbs DOWN:  Gravy colored walls and so-so food.
author: Jeff C.

description:
UNPRETENTIOUS!!
Tyger's is a wonderful neighborhood restaurant with yummy food at great prices. The staff is always warm and friendly. Most of the customers are regulars who are greeted by their first name from the waitresses who have worked there forever. My husband I and go in there almost every weekend for breakfast. Their pancakes are my favorite in San Francisco!! For less than $7, you can get eggs, your choice of meat or vegan sausage like me if you're a veg, and pancakes so big they need their own plate! Also, the restaurant is full of normal, non-hipster folks who are interested in good food at good prices instead of the decor. It's usually crowded on the weekends, but I've never waited more than 5 minutes for a table.
author: Cindi K.

description:
The food isn't spectacular by SF standards, or even, say, Indiana standards. Actually, "standards" would be a good word to describe the menu, which primarily consists of American classics. Western omelettes. French toast with walnuts. Patty melts. Freedom fres. The stuff we started liking when we were three years old.

And the safety of the menu is part of Tyger's charm. It does feel a wee bit like chowing in someone's home. The wall behind the cash register is plastered with photos of neighbor kids and pictures of tigers, the feline type. 

You won't be wowed, but you'll come back.
author: Eric M.

description: We came here a little after 12pm, there was a small wait, but wasn't too bad.  This place is small, 14 tables total.  I had the hot sausage omelet, it was delicious.  HUGE portion for under $10.  I will def. come back.
author: Oriana C.

description:
I live in Glen Park and had never gone. I know I know, what the hell is wrong with me? Given the fact that there are a total of 6 or so places to eat in GP it's absurd that today was the day.

Well, if their sign wasn't so misleading, things would be diff't. I probably would've eaten there 50 times by now. Thing is their sign says "coffee shop" and that's misleading because you can get a burger there. I don't know of many coffee shops you can get a burger at so I just assumed the joint was a straight coffee+pastry joint.

Well, I was wrong. It should be called Tyger's Diner because that's what it is. It's a diner.

Anyway, I go in today, rock a french toast combo breakfast with a coffee and it was straight. Pretty good, not mind blowing.

French toast combo = french toast, 2 eggs, and your choice of meat (I went with sausage).

French toast: B+. Pretty good, not "holy-shit-this-is-blowing-my-mind."

Eggs: C. Should've gone w/ over-easy. The scrambled were kinda sub-par.

Sausage links: A+. "Holy-shit-these-sausage-links-are-blowing-my-mind."

Overall, it was a solid diner breakfast experience. Will definitely go back.

BTW, my combo+coffee came out to $10 and change w/o tip. Bit pricey, but not steep.
author: Gil M.

description:
I came here with a good friend of mine 5 years ago and I still remember it to this day for some very strange reason. I came here with another good friend of mine and the food was still good.

I ordered the bacon, swiss, and mushroom omelet and it came with a side of home fries. I love me some potatoes and I was actually going to order a side of them after seeing people eating them at other tables but decided not to as I was looking for hashbrowns (which they don't have any). I don't think they mentioned it on their menu that the omelet came with potatoes but it worked out in the end. The omelet was great; the bacon wasn't overly salty and the egg still had a spring to it (I don't like runny omelets or overcooked omelets). It was definitely good and I could see myself ordering it again.

My friend ordered a rueben sandwich and although he said he liked it, it didn't look that appetizing to me personally, but I'll take his word on it. My friend lives nearby so he frequents this place pretty often so I'm sure he knows more about this place than I do. Overall, the service is pretty good and the food is good so I definitely see myself coming back again.
author: Richard C.

description:
"Oh my God. It's SO FLUFFY. I'm gonna die!" Yes I'm talking about the pancakes. The pancakes are not only HUMUNGO JUNGO but they are SO FLUFFFFY! I got bacon, eggs, and buttermilk pancakes. The prices in this place is LEGIT! Very cheap. Very tasty. Worth the money. 

It's a small area and pretty diner feeling. It's pretty janky setting but w/e. The pancakes are SO FLUFFY! I can't say it enough. If you're in a pancake craving mode, then Tyger's is the place to go. Best pancakes I've ever had. I got full off of that bacon, eggs, and pancakes meal. I'm a big guy and it takes a lot to fill me up. Those two slabs of pancakes alone would have gotten me plump like a Foster Farm Chicken! Ahhhhhh, it's so delicious too. Yes I've only been there once but it was an amazing experience. 

Fast service. It's on a corner, so parking might be hard to find. But yeee dog.
author: Philbert K.

description:
A no-frills greasy spoon that services with a smile.

I had the walnut french toast served with a mound of melting butter, I looked for the syrup - nowhere to be seen!

I caught the honey bear container in the corner of my eye, that usually is filled with honey - but gotcha! Filled with syrup, the rest of the meal went swimmingly...
author: wayne s.

description: I want to love this place since it's our new neighborhood local breakfast joint. But the last couple of times I've been there, I couldn't even finish my omelette. It just wasn't good. Dining companion felt the same. Bathroom way in the back is pretty nasty.  Breakfast usually isn't that hard to mess up, and I love lots of diner food.  I don't eat pancakes, I'm sure those are likely better than any of the egg dishes.
author: Megan H.

description:
A decent place, in every sense.  I love the cheesy pictures of tigers, the never-changing menu, and the pictures of the Diamond/Chenery intersection years ago.

     I live nearby, and I dive in here whenever I need to just relax and fill my stomach.  Many mornings I sit down, read a book, and eat a pile of bacon, mushrooms, and swiss cheese loosely wrapped in an omelette.  Sometimes the food seems bland, espescially with a taqueria like La Corneta right down the street, but there is a rack of boutique hot sauces under the register if you want some kick.  I'll probably keep dropping by, when I'm in a neighborhoody kind of mood, but a city like this one has a lot more to offer with a little bit of effort.

     This is my first review, so tell me what you think.
author: Eric S.

description:
Summary:
I would go back for breakfast again. It is worth a try if you are in Glen Park.

My Story:
Stopped in on a Monday morning after picking up my dry cleaning. Got a Pumpkin and Walnut pancake which was good. You get two big flap jacks that are heavy for about six bucks. I got the food to go but the lady was nice about ringing me up and getting the food to me quickly. I ate one right away and saved the second. After cooling off in the fridge all day, the pancake was like a desert. Real good but not something you can eat daily.

Ordered:
Pumpkin and Walnut Pancakes
author: Scott H.

description: This was a solid, yummy greasy breakfast. My husband had the french toast and didn't like it (too cinnamony not much other flavor), but I had buckwheat pancakes that were fluffy and awesome, even if they had way too much butter on top. Very generous servings- your basic greasy diner food. Bacon was good, sausage was eh, like out of the package Jimmy Dean style. I thought the coffee was pretty good.  Service was fast and friendly, you can tell they have a dedicated neighborhood clientele.
author: Nicole A.

description:
So good it is making me re-rate my other diner reviews.  

Every time I come here the service is quick and friendly.  If I have to wait, it is never long enough to annoy me.  I'm always pleasantly surprised by the vegan sausages (not necessarily their quality, but the fact that they're available).  Quick service, great collection of hot sauces, reasonable prices, a bar section - everything I require in a diner.

I just wish there were formica tables - a diner just ain't a diner without them. 

That and I just never can get used to places where you have to walk through the kitchen to use the bathroom.  I know space is a premium, but it really puts into perspective my level of hygeine (medium to low) and its relation to everyone else (usually lower than mine - of course).  Ick.
author: Mat K.

description:
I get that this place has been around forever has a dedicated following that goes back generations.  I'm just not one of them.
I found their food to be mediocre at best.  The menu is blah, nothing new or different and much of it was greasy.  I do have to give them credit for the bacon, which was super crispy and thick, just the way I like it.  But, everything else...I'll pass.
author: Jessica L.

description: Excellent greasy spoon. Great coffee, delicious food, large portions. Very friendly staff / owners. The only drawback is that on weekends you can expect a line outside.
author: Angel C.

description: They make one of the best fluffiest pancakes I have ever eaten.  Waitresses there have been working for years.  Service is quick and friendly.  This place is my favorite breakfast place to get some delicious tasting pancakes and their french toast are delicious!  I feel like my meals are always hearty and orange juice is yummy delicious.
author: pengrin ..

description:
Tyger's is a place I wrote off after my first visit as being just another greasy spoon, one that offered little, if anything, I wanted in my mouth.  But then I went back on a whim and everything was different for me this second time.  

I can't recall what I had exactly on that second visit to change my disposition toward the locale, but my attitude was different.  Maybe it was the variety of meat options available as a side to a couple of eggs--how often do you find turkey bacon on a menu of an average diner?  

My best experience ever at Tyger's was when I enjoyed a plate of hot  pumpkin pancakes.  It was a special, one that comes and goes, but if you ever are lucky enough to be in Tyger's when they are serving pumpkin pancakes, try them.  

The service is friendly.  The place is clean.  The is usually a wait by 10:00 am on the weekends, but the service is speedy, so the turn over is quick too.
author: Katie P.

description:
Only had to wait about 10 minutes to get a seat on a Saturday morning, which I don't think is too bad for a breakfast joint around here.  The food was worth the wait.  EGGS AND MEAT. That's what I like in my breakfast, and lot's of it.  And I want tons of flavor in those eggs and meat.  
They delivered.

For once though, I would love a normal, run of the mill breakfast place to have delicious coffee.
author: Levi B.

description:
Solid breakfast place - nothing fancy, just large portions of American food.  It's perfect after a night out, when you're tired and hung over.

Their lunch is also pretty good. I've only had the Veggie Melt sandwich - a grilled cheese with fresh vegetables and avocado inside it - and it hits the spot.

Overall - if you're looking for a nice brunch experience, this isn't the place, but if you want a solid, reasonably-priced, breakfast, Tyger's is the place to go.
author: Sekhar S.

description: well executed standard breakfast.  coffee from the 1950's (cuppaJoe-style). Bacon is half pre-cooked, so arrives quick and crispy, but grease-soaked and not hot enough.
author: Josh K.

description: Tyger's is an awesome breakfast spot that is conveniently located down the block from my house. I always get either an omelette or a burger (bacon, avocado, mushroom) with a side of awesomeness a.k.a. Tyger's home fries. The portions are very generous and the food is always fresh and delicious. The people that work here are great. One word to describe the service is welcoming. I always feel at home at Tyger's. The food comes out very quickly and always with a smile. Oh, and yes there usually is a line going out the door, but since I can see the front of the place from my window I dash down the block and cut in front of people trying to get in line. Suckers, me first.
author: Alexander C.

description:
It has been said but i will affirm.  Good greasy hangover fix.  For some reason, i crave good brewed ice tea the morning after, and they had that so i was pretty much set.

I have a veggie omelet, and the veggies were all nice and crisp which like.    I could have used a few more potatoes tho.

Decently cheap, and there was no wait on a friday morning which was awesome.
author: Darryl S.

description:
When I was living in Glen Park, going to Tyger's felt almost the same as rolling out of bed & walking into the kitchen.  It's that cozy, that comfortable, just like home.

It's not the food, not the service that keeps you coming back.  It's the feeling that this is a comfortable place to be.  Sometimes that's more than enough...
author: Seth S.

description: Friendly staff and affordable breakfast made to order - a great neighborhood gem.
author: Bradley H.

description: A fabulous, affordable, classic greasy-spoon style diner. Love the staff. They're busy but they'll get to you. Just bring your check up to the counter for a faster exit. Everything from egg scrambles, omlettes, sandwiches, fries, and pancakes are yummy. I especially like their turkey sausage links, which seem spicy but not too salty and greasy.
author: Lotion M.

description:
The best word to describe this place is "bleh".  If I am hungover it is actually decent otherwise almost unbearable.  The prices are affordable for the neighborhood and the service is fast.  The food is just not very good.  

Once the eggs in my omelette were undercooked (ewwww!).  Since I know I will be back one day, half drunk and desperate for pancakes with a half a cup of margarine on top, it is only fair to give it 3 stars.
author: Jessica E.

description: This place is the best. i have been coming here for over 10 years now and they still remember my name. I could skip out for months and when I come back BOOM they cal me by my first name. I have tried nearly everything here and will tell you that the specials are worth giving a once over. They have great sausages, omelets and even burgers.
author: E T.

description:
Standard diner fare, served without attitude or pretension.  Hearty and filling, it is all that you want it to be and nothing that it is not.  The price is right and it's not so nice a place that you want to read your paper there, taking up valuable eating space...  Eat and get out and let the people in line follow suit.

While I will not roar about Tyger's, it gets a contented purr and a happy meow from me.
author: Tony A.

description:
I rolled up in this place with a toddler in tow and the diner/cafe completely packed!  I was sat next to the window, which was nice.  People watching!  The bus boy quickly took my carriage and stowed it away and brought me an old, but working fairly well, high chair.  

Our server was very busy and was short with me, but I quickly ordered a sandwich and a ground burger for the tot.  Lunch came.  I was disappointed with the sandwich and the ground burger was not that.  It was a whole patty, but I faired ok.

I don't know, I felt a bit rushed and I felt the service was not that great.  A bit disappointing, but I guess I can understand since she was slammed.

I would have given it 4 stars if our server would have been a tad more attentive and if my sandwich had a bit more meat.  The meat was scarce and I suppose I should have said something.  But, time is of the essence when you're with someone at the age of just one.

Props to the lady who came over to help me figure out the dinosaur highchair.  Thank you!!

Doubt I'll be back again, but everything is worth trying at least once.
author: Kat M.

description: I lived across the street and I loved the convenience of the place. Other than the convenience factor I really would not venture from another side of town to check this place out. The food is very cheap which is great, but the quality is ok. So all in all if you live near glen park check em out.
author: J B.

description: This place is super packed on the weekends. It's a little to cramped for my test. However the food was quite good. The service was quick and friendly. The turkey sausage is yummy.  Just get in early. Otherwise you have people hovering over you while you eat.
author: Sandy P.

description:
I have to admit that Tyger's has some REALLY GOOD breakfast! I live right up the street and my boyfriend & I ALWAYS go here for breakfast. The omelettes are amazingly good and I love the "specials" they have! I've been to other places that sell the same omlettes and no where can compare to Tygers. However I had to give it minus 1 star because service there COULD be better. Here are my reasons:

1. When it's JAM-PACKED (and it does get like that OFTEN.. sometimes people wait in line outside the diner for 30+ mins!) and you want to order a "TO-GO" item.. the wait is FOREVER! I waited about 45 mins for my to-god! UGH.

2. The ONLY GUY waiter there is NOT an example of good customer service. There was one time when my boyfriend & I ordered a omelette w/ potatoes.. the potatoes there ALWAYS taste RAW AND UNDERCOOKED so we asked to make them extra cooked/cripsy whatever on both of our orders and he said "OK, ONLY ONE THOUGH BECAUSE IT TAKES A LONG TIME" You just DO NOT say that to a customer.. that's RUDE!

3. They have gotten my order wrong quite a few times. Once when I ordered a to-go burger for my mom. I wanted it EXTRA WELL DONE AND I EMPHASIZED NO RED AT ALL TO THEM & WHEN I GOT HOME IT WAS STILL RED. There was also another time when I ordered a omlette (TO-GO) and the omelette automatically comes with toast. I said I wanted english muffin and when I got home, the toast wasn't even there! Nowadays when I go there I just make shure that it's there before I go so I can catch them right then and there if something's wrong.

Regardless of their wrongdoings I still don't let it stop me from going there because their food is A+! The great tasting food makes up for the not so good service. :)
author: Sarah E.

description: Great place to come for a classic breakfast. The pancakes are great and so is the chili.
author: Andres M.

description:
Tyger's makes a decent breakfast, and the staff is nice. 

However, one word of caution: avoid the meatloaf sandwich. It looks and tastes like crap. Or order it and see for yourself--and let me know what your thoughts are on what it's made of. Even though I had no idea what was in it, I put some tabasco on it and ate it all, but that's because I'm a goddamn cheapskate, not because it was edible.
author: AJ C.

description: I truly believe that decent breakfast places are like public utilities; their presence in all districts is to be expected, like hydrants or mailboxes. In fact the more low-key they are, the better. Nothing fancy-schmancy here. Check out the favorite start to a weekend morning--not-too-early seating at Tyger's, crispy eggs sunnyside-up, pork sausage, buttered pancakes, and cheery buzz from neighbors talking, smacking lips, rustling the Chronicle. The word neighbors here is important because though I love the food and the ambience you might not get it. To each her own. You might ask, What's the big deal? Friendly efficient staff, neighborliness, traditional American breakfast (tasty and cheap) is what. I got mine but, sorry to say, you'll have to find your own perfectly comfy morning cafe. Ask for extra butter if you must. Coffee keeps a-coming. Check out multiple hot sauces shelved low near the counter.
author: John T.

description: I would put Tyger's in the category of "greasy spoon diner". It's like truck stop food. If you think of it in this vein you won't be disappointed because it's decent truck stop food...
author: Bleep S.

description: I still love this place.  San Francisco is so inundated with new, trendy, and pricey places to brunch/breakfast, sometimes you need a break. Tyger's is old San Francisco to me and very comfortable.
author: A R.

description: Bar none, the best pancakes in the city...and they have buckwheat pancakes, too.  This place is not frilly or refined, but what it does wonderfully is old school delicious breakfasts.   I've been eating there for 20 years, and they're consistently delicious.  Wish they offered eggs benedict on a regular basis...the only complaint.
author: Julie T.

description: I liked Tyger's because it is so unpretentious.  Plus since I don't eat red meat I really appreciate the abundance of turket bacon and sausage choices.  I love their Club Sandwich that is made completely from turkey products (ham, bacon and turkey slices!).  Get it with fries which are perfectly hot and crunchy.  Hot sauce lovers note: they have about 25 different hot sauces available for your enjoyment and sampling.
author: Xander S.

description: Great breakfast place, love the home fries. I been there like about 5 times, I usually try something different on the specials menu.  Totally dig the different  flavored pancakes.
author: Harold G.

description:
As a Glen Park resident, I love coming to Tyger's on a Sat or Sun morning.  There is often a line outside on the weekends, but this restuarant offers a perfect combination of great breakfast food, unique specials and a homely, neighborhood feel.  

The food is not particularly fancy, but it is well done and the staff is very friendly.  You cannot go wrong with the daily specials.
author: Niraj P.

description: Cheap, quick, decent breakfast.  Old school diner type place.  The cool thing about this place is their extensive selection of hot sauce.  I mean, this place has about 30 or 40 hot sauces to choose from and some of these hot sauces are EVIL, so use caution when experimenting with them on your scrambled baby chickens.
author: Christina S.

description: Another weekend, another breakfast joint. Ventured out to Glen Park this time for my San Francisco breakfast explorations. My friend recommended Tyger's and was like it's just a classic diner, which it is, and I love it! They have all your standards and you can tell it's just a family run establishment and all the people who come here are from around the neighborhood and have been coming here for ages. Love it!! I had the bacon, avocado, sour cream omelet with home fries and sourdough toast. Service is fast and efficient and their home fries in particular stood out. Crispy on the outside, soft on the inside with bits of garlic and onion. Really tasty! We didn't get the pancakes but saw someone who did and they were HUGE and fluffy and smelled amazing! Next time I'm getting the pancakes.
author: Cathy T.

description: I love this place, LOVE, LOVE, LOVE! They have awesome omelets and the walnut raisin waffles are AMAZING!
author: Michael F.

description:
i love this place, its totally OG. ive been coming here since i 
wasn't even born yet. a good mix of old-san francisco people like school teachers, funny lookin old people, people with children and filipino people.

i like when they have country gravy over TOAST (F over biscuits).

Horrible coffee (some of the worst in the city, sometimes tasting like a dirty dishrag)

inconsistent (albiet fresh squeezed) orange juice. sometimes they just happen to use not so tasty oranges.

over-all all people should try tyger cafe once.
author: christopher a.

description: This place gets 5 stars because I feel it has perfected a form... the coziest diner, friendliest staff, fastest service, and best diner-style food. It really shouldn't be compared with some fancy schmancy place twice the price. There was a 2 minute wait on a Saturday morning, and DELICIOUS food- we had the pumpkin-walnut pancakes and corned beef hash, with nice strong coffee, for about 15 bucks. Now, if only I could afford to live in Glen Park.
author: Emily B.

description: I had lunch here for the first time and I went to sit down on my seat and sat right down on a pile of sour cream ... nice.  The waitress apologized and immediately began to clean up the mess that was missed when the table was cleared :(  I had a tuna melt sandwich which was very tasty but didn't come with any sides (which had to be ordered separately).   My friend had the Reuben and she really enjoyed her meal as well!
author: Shaw Y.

description: Like previous Yelpers have said, the portions are large.  The food is very good and very affordable.  It is a standard bare-bones neighborhood coffee house with good home-style food.  You can't go wrong with a visit to this place.
author: Marjorie G.

description: I've come here for breakfast and lunch a few times in two years. The service is excellent, the food is good, and the prices are consistent. It's your basic greasy spoon diner-type establishment. It's that small-town, remember your name, butter-comes-in-a-small-cup, kind of place. Hung over? Great! This is where you go. Early morning and later mornings towards lunch seem to be the best times to come.
author: Christian D.

description: Come to Tyger's for classic diner breakfast. The portions are generous. The staff is real. And the chicken sausage is waiting for you. I'll even have pancakes here and I'm very picking about my breakfast food.
author: Angela K.

description: Tygers is one of my favorite diners in SF (and that's saying a LOT because I love breakfast).  I sit at the counter and get great attention from the woman there.  This place is always busy on the weekends (and they are only open for breakfast/lunch), but the wait is never too bad.  When  they have the eggs benedict on the special menu, don't miss it!  Always check the white board for specials, they are consistently good.  This is worth a trip to cute little Glen park.  Only 1 block from GP BART.
author: Dayna V.

description: A great neighborhood spot for some classic breakfast items. Nothing fancy, just decent food.  The buckwheat pancakes are great (without the gigantic dollop of butter of course).
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description: Tyger's is crowded, but I've never had to wait that long.  The service is friendly and efficient, and the food is good.  I really like the apple pancakes.
author: Andi T.

description: The food is not really that great.  It reminds me of stuff I can make quickly at home.  There is a long wait.  The prices are too high for what you get.  If you are looking to be surrounded by many people, then maybe this is for you.  But as far as the food goes, noo, skip it.
author: see y.

description: Tyger's is dependable in that Mom & Pop way. The food is good; solid takes on diner fare that make some accommodations to California palates (like turkey bacon instead of the regular stuff and no fear of avocados). The potato salad is a little on the sweet side for my taste, but they get points for using Dijon instead of American Technicolor. Also, they serve Crystal hot sauce at the tables, so they definitely get extra points for that. Pretty good pancakes and french toast, too. Be prepared for a wait on weekend mornings.
author: Alberto Y.

description: Good old fashioned greasy spoon at its best.  I'll be honest, I've only ever been here when I was hungover, but man does it satisfy barfy stomach.  The special pumpkin walnut pancakes are incredible, they should put them on the menu full time.
author: Caleb R.

description:
it's not really the best, but i can't give tygers anything under 5 stars. i love it here. i have literally been coming here since birth. i went recently and had the andouille sausage with potatoes, eggs, and toast. HUGE ass plate, stuffed myself and it was like 6 bucks. 

i like this place because there are so many different kinds of people that come here and the lady who works here is great. she has framed photographs of her kids on the walls too.

super fast service.
author: Samantha G.

description:
Best pancakes and I usually don't even order pancakes but I eat these ones!
Get the pancakes you will not be disappointed they are so good.
author: Judy J.

description: I have eaten here many times before, like most Im a local to the area.  But the last few times the food has gone downhill, and today's experience had me look up Tygers Cafe on yelp to see what people are saying about it.  Seems like most support this place because its local to them, and they have a relationship with the owners, but that cannot be a reason to give this place 4 or even 3 stars. The food is greasy, and loaded with butter. I watched Suzy scoop butter of pancakes, blot it with napkins and proceed to serve it to customers. They manage to ruin eggs for me the last 3 times I have  been there, and the service is mediocre at best. There is no quality to the food- if you dont believe me take a look at their "splenda", jelly, and hot sauce-all cheap no name brands that lack quality. They seem to cut corners but the prices on the menu do not reflect that. Im not saying its expensive, just comparable to many other QUALITY breakfast places. I can say I will never go back to Tygers after todays experience- which is a bummer because its within walking distance.
author: Ken A.

description: People line up outside of this place on weekends, and I don't understand why. Okay, I've only eaten there once, but it was enough to know that the food Tyger's serves is strictly mediocre. Not to diss them -- it's a real neighborhood spot, and the same customers eat breakfast there every morning. It's a nice place to have around, atmosphere-wise, but I seek my brunches (when I do manage to get up on Saturday or Sunday in time) elsewhere.
author: Tara M.

description: I'm here to defend Tygers.  Okay, okay, it may not look that great from the outside or the inside for that matter.  But here's why it deserves four stars: the food is good, they give a lot of it, and it's fairly cheap.
author: Helen C.

description: I enjoy tygers in the morning after wild parting the night before. Its perfect hangover breakfast. I also enjoy the waitresses, they have been there forever.
author: Francisca H.

description: Tyger's is tasty and a good place to meet up with friends for a slow breakfast. This is a decent meeting place where you can linger and talk for a long time.  Not a "city" place, reminds you of the suburbs.
author: Tyler W.

description: Breakfasted there today with my gf. Paula  nice, quaint, Glen Park area spot. We ordered a full stack of the buckwheat pancakes and a shrimp, spinach and sour cream omelette.  The pancakes were by far the best, as the omelet was runny and not really good at all. Nice place, very reasonably priced. They do not accept credit cards as well... which is always a bit of a drag because honestly who carries cash with them now? But thankfully BoA and Wells Fargo ATMs are literally steps away, so it's not so bad.
author: John G.

description: Very homley type meals. I used to go here on a regular basis with my master's rowing team for Sunday Brunch. No better way than to rack up all those calories we just burned off rowing for a few hours. Ohh I love it =)
author: Alia D.

description: I have been coming here for years for their breakfast standards.  I started coming back again with my bf who, like me, loves their fluffy pancakes.  This is a reliable place for us to go on lazy weekends.
author: V B.

description: Even in sleepy Glen Park, you can find a good breakfast and a reasonably priced burger. The service at Tyger's is amiable and efficient even in crowded situations. And yeah, the decor is a little behind the times, but not everyone has an inner interior designer or can afford to hire one.
author: Be N.

description: As a native of San Francisco, who may have been temporarily displaced elsewhere, I have to say, HERE'S TO THE GREASY SPOON. Having seen the city go through so many transformations, and knowning that we are a foodie institution in the country, you gotta give it up to greasy spoon's like Tyger's that uphold some of the old school, traditional character of this city! Tyger's has that for me. Yes they have weird takes on California cuisine (chicken enchilada's and eggs, that is truly something I see my self eating while intoxicated or as a poor college student) the food is decent diner fare great pancakes, specials, the hash(!) and scrambles. It's truly disheartening to see people so against places like these, especially ones that didn't let the dot com bomb disrupt their flow.  To Tyger's!
author: Niki M.

description:
this place always reminds me of the small roadhouse diners i remember eating at during vacations "up north" as a kid in wisconsin. wood paneling, family run, hearty breakfasts make it all a worthwhile trip.

lots of syrup, ketchup and hot sauce on the tables.

ridiculously good hot chocolate for coming out of a machine.

fair prices and frequent coffee refills.

plus they have veggie sausage, just to remind you that you're in sanny franny.
author: Joanna R.

description: It's a great neighborhood spot for a big breakfast and the coffee is very good.  It's not a gourmet delight, but the food is hearty and there's LOTS of it.
author: jill c.

description: Good ol Tyger's.  What can I say that everyone else here hasn't already?  Great food, great environment.  Little jam packed, and feels a little cramped at times, but then again I'm 6'3"
author: Sean V.

description: Great food , great service. You get the feeling your in the sticks when your here. The interior has not been redone probably since the place opened ,oh around sixty years or so ago..?
author: Jack O.

description: This place is not the best and its not that cheap but if you live near by its not bad. The foods good but when I lived near by I would jump on the bart and go somewhere else.
author: Mike L.

description: As a night owl, it takes a lot of persuasion to get me out of the house at a decent time, particularly on the weekends when I am even more lazy (is that possible?) But Tyger's has the fluffiest egg omelets ever and the staff is friendly, prices are fine, and like some other reviewers have said it is just a great place to eat without being trendy, so overly self-conscious, and all that other frou-frou crap. Do not come here expecting a hip brunch with mimosas, it is just well done eggs, pancakes, sausage that kind of thing. And yes, parking is quite limited at Glen Park. It is very close to BART and there are several bus lines as well.
author: Empress C.

description: My friends used to live up the street from here, and there were many a times when we go to tyger's for hangover goodness. tyger's is you basic semi-greasy breakfast joint with good food. The only complaints that i have with this place is they're cash only. This place is relatively small and if you don't get there at the crack of dawn on the weekends, the wait can be almost 30 minutes.
author: Lynette R.

description:
awe, i love glen park.  i lived there for 2.5 years, and they were absolutely blissful.  in part, to sunday mornin' breakfast at tyger's in my jammies.

small place, so you have to wait outside, but if you time it right, you can walk on in.  i often just go and eat there alone while reading the paper.  the wait staff is so great.  they've all worked there for FORever and so it's got that home feel.  you know, pictures of everyone's kids up on the wall, ect.

food is yummy.  pretty much traditional american cafe food, cooked anyway you want, and always to perfection.  

the best part about location, is the glen park canyon is right there!  so i always like to eat and then take a nice walk in nature to let it all settle :-)

check it oooooooooout!
author: nzingha s.

description: Sincerely good greasy spoon fare.
author: David T.

description: I love Tyger's for what it isn't!  It isn't fancy, it isn't pretentious and everyone is treated like family.   It is a true Mom and Pop from a bygone era.  Most importantly - even after all this time - the food and smiles come in healthy portions.  Any given Sunday - I'll be there!
author: Dean F.

description: I like Tyger's quite a bit.  My husband has been going here since he was a lil' one, and we like to go whenever we can. Fwiw, when my parents visit from Atlanta, this is their first stop in SF!  Try the rasberry or punpkin pancakes.  They are delicious!
author: Mairin M.

description: Tyger's is exactly what you'd want in a neighborhood diner; the kind of friendly, reasonable, and reliable place that inspires loyal devotion.  We've been Sunday regulars for over a decade now, and when out-of-towners visit, they don't just come to see us or San Francisco -- they come to have breakfast at Tyger's.  A good-weather weekend means you may have to wait for a table, but it's never long and always worth it.  Cash only, but within a couple of blocks of Wells Fargo, Bank of America and Citibank ATMs.
author: Danny R.

description: This place is great for a diner-type breakfast. But the food is better quality, their sausage links are awesome and their burgers (yes I am still talking about breakfast) are mighty tasty. Also they have a surprising number of chalkboard specials, and I've never had a bad one.  On Saturday morning you might have to wait out front for ten minutes for a table, but doesn't that just make everything taste better once you are finally seated? This place is solid, no frills, you won't leave disappointed.
author: Luke S.

description:
The breakfast here was okay.  It wasnt horrible but wasn't great.  I'd give it 2 1/2 stars instead.  Place is small and packed on a Sunday brunch.  Food was overly greasy.

If your looking for a good breakfast joint, go to Howards Cafe or Art's Cafe in the Inner Sunset.  I guarantee you'll taste the difference.
author: K T.

description: This is a good place for a cheap, but tastey meal. The menu is mostly breakfast foods, but they serve it all day long (at least through lunch). All sorts of burgers and sandwiches too. Simple, unaffected diner type place in a nice little neighborhood.
author: Caitlin H.

description: Awesome eggs and burgers. Can get crowded on weekends but is worth the wait. Staff are friendly and ready to refill coffee and water with a smile.
author: Tony J.

description: This place is always good.  Every Sat and Sun there's a line around the corner trying to get into this place.  Great breakfast!!  Worth the wait.
author: Ryan Y.

description: this is a five star basic fare breakfast joint. if you have to scan the menu for something not considered basic fare, you are at the wrong place.  eggs toast pancakes bacon keep it simple and you wont be disappointed.
author: pablo p.

description: I agree with most of what's been said here.  Really good American style diner food.  Breakfast and lunch is dependable, fresh with large portions. Service is swift and no frills.  There aren't too many places like this around anymore.  Reasonably priced also.
author: LA T.

description: 5 Stars for Tyger's pancakes.  Been around the world, eaten lots of pancakes. No place can hold a candle to Tyger's.  When (and if) I get to heaven, I'm sure it'll be very nice and all but I doubt they'll have Tyger's pancakes.  Oh, and they're fast and friendly.
author: Colin M.

description:
I guess I'd describe Tyger's  as a typical greasy spoon breakfast joint (not that it's dirty, just that type of ambience), but with a slightly more interesting menu (spicy italian sausage breakfasts, etc)... 
 
Great bacon & french toast
author: Nose Z.

description: This place is ok, full of regulars but honestly the food is just ok. I'm a little suspect of a breakfast place that can't properly cook an over-medium egg. For syrup they use the cheapest corn-syrup based syrup---for the prices they charge they could upgrade to a better syrup, that would help!
author: meg o.

description: Good breakfast and prices. The pancakes were yummy.
author: m m.

description: You don't go to a place like this expecting fine cusine, nor expecting to be able to order something vegan. Surprise of all ages though, there is vegan sausage on the menu! And it was delicious! Sometimes you just need to get out of the neighborhood, and Glen Park is great for imagining your alternative suburban lifestyle. What I like about the corner where Tyger's is located is how much is reminds me of a small Yorkshire town in England, apart from the lack of brick or cobblestone (and teenage moms) - a tiny cluster of shops and cafes in tiny buildings up and down a series of twisty hills, except with a gourmet health food store where 50% of the customers are yuppies, Russians, or both, a tapioca internet cafe and pleasant, nevermind tolerable, weather. The "y" in the name along with the greasy generic food and atmosphere of the place really brought me back to my days in the industrial North. Except the food is way better, and there's no way in hell you'd get vegetarian sausage OR fresh fruit in a place like this in Leeds or Sheffield, or even London for that matter. That said, it cost $10.50 for the said fruit and sausage plus some home fries. I can't in good food-loving conscience give it anything more than three stars because while it's not terrible, it's definitely not amazing, and clearly, they're just not looking to create the best food ever. It's the general mood of the place you're after here, a cozy, sweet, elderly, anachronistic trashy-yet-homey traditional cafe-diner, or in the words of the owners, a place with "uniqueness and quasi-quaintness." (what?)
author: Jessalyn A.

description: Best unpretentious breakfast in SF.  I challenge you to find me a place that has better pancakes.  If you like tofu or bree in your breakfast, it's obvious this isn't the place for you.
author: Jose W.

description: good breakfeast always eat here when in sf. if they banana pancakes jump on them
author: Tom M.

description: The food isn't fantastic, just basic diner food with some hits and some misses, but the place and the owners are nice and down to earth. A very comfortable place to bring friends and family.
author: Peter L.

description: Tygers is not that greasy of a greasy spoon.  On weekday mornings you see the same old-timer regulars.  Buckwheat pancakes are great.  Waitresses very peppy.  Good prices, nothing too fancy.
author: Christine N.

description: 5 stars? Tyger's is a standard ma and pa with a gum chewing waitress (actually no gum, but she does say "Sweetie" now and then), satisfying breakfast fare and really bad coffee. Reliable standards with heartland condiments (Kraft Mayo, ketchup, etc). The usual artery clogging brunch. It's great advantage is that it is neighborhood and unpretentious. Lots of kids, tables that can take larger parties and no reservations. No laptops, or not yet. You go there to eat. Sunday papers ok. Tuna melts and BLT's are just that: Tuna melts and BLT's. Decent pricing, nice old hippie owner and a counter with stools. You wouldn't have to drag me there with ten horses, but on the other hand, I wouldn't take a detour. There are a bunch of decent locations in Glen Park, and West Portal. Small groups only.
author: Otto S.
